loans.name: Yee

texts.en: Yee S., 51, is married with six children children. She lives with her husband in Battambong Province Province. To make a living, her husband operates his motorbike attached with a trailer in the town, typically earning US $5 per day which is the primary source of income for the family.  Her husband has to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for the family and the children. The family also assisted by two of the children who are currently employed in a local hotel as drivers with a reasonable income to make a good living and to assist the family. S. is seeking to increase her income and start a new business. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to buy all of sugar canes in stock from the local farmer in her province and sell them back in fairly profitable price. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: buy all of sugar canes in stock

loans.name: Claudio

texts.en:
Claudio E. is from the village of Brgy. 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 55 years-old and unmarried. Claudio owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Claudio has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Claudio joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Claudio is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Claudio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products.

loans.name: Nhoeb

texts.en: S., 37, had married to Jame, 48, who is a local farmer. She always helps her husband farming rice and planting rice besides her work. S. is good at making bamboo baskets for the market. She and her husband take sometimes through the village seeking for bamboos and take them home and then put them into water for almost a week after that dry them under the sunshine three days. They split the bamboos into smaller pieces after that her husband and her start making them to basket. Recently, S. is taking a loan to invest in her handicap business. She dreams of having a degree for her children.

loans.use: to invest in her handicap business.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is from the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Due to difficulties in her life, she was not able to pursue her college education. She then started to work to help her parents earn a living. She is married to Willie and they have not yet been blessed with a child.

Thelma’s husband works as a security guard in one of the banks in Nueva Vizcaya while Thelma manages their sari-sari store (village store) at home. She is asking to borrow financial capital to be added to her revolving capital in her store. She believes that PHP 20,000 will be of big help in the expansion of her store. She will utilize the amount to acquire different grocery items, cases of soft drinks and frozen foods at Solano Public Market that she will retail in her store.

The average income she earns every month amounts to PHP 5,000 which she uses as rolling capital. She aims to earn a higher income so that she is able to save for future emergencies in their lives. She believes that, someday, she will be able to improve her business by means of patience, hard work and the continuous support of Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S. (shown with her mom) is 53 years old and sells fruit and cakes in the local market of Phnom Penh city. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$5 every day.

Selling fruit has been a difficult business as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Meas is asking for a loan of US$500 to put into her fruit business to increase her stock of fruit. She sees this investment as an opportunity that will enable her to increase her daily income.

loans.use: To invest in her fruit stand

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida Y., 44, lives with her husband Robert, 39, a market vendor, amongst the poor communities of Pasay City. They have seven children, all but one of whom are in school. Aida has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) since 2006.

Aida owns and manages a stall inside a market complex selling different types of footwear, such as sandals and flip-flops. She started this business six years ago. Her market stall is very near a commuter train station, making it accessible to buyers. Her sandals are in demand so she employs an assistant to help her attend to customers. She makes 34,000 PHP a month, enough to sustain her family’s needs, including education expenses for her children. She has been able to purchase a motorized tricycle, which now provides an additional source of income for the family.

Competition amongst individual entrepreneurs in the market complex is prevalent and inevitable; this however, is healthy competition. Aida needs a loan of 50,000 PHP to be able to purchase more stock of sandals and flip-flops to give customers more options from which to choose. Aida spends time and money visiting manufacturers of sandals and other footwear to obtain a better selection. That’s why she dreams of having her own vehicle to transport her goods. She also wishes to have her own house and lot soon.

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of sandals and flip-flops

loans.name: Phum

texts.en: Phum C. is a widow with four children children. She resides in Battambong Province Province. To make a living, she works as a construction worker everywhere in the province, typically earning US $2.5 per day which is the primary source of income for the family. One of her children is also a construction worker with his mother to assist the family. Both of them try to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for the family. She is asking for a loan of US $150 to buy construction implements for her child to improve his business. (She is pictured while she is preparing lunch for her children)

loans.use: buy suppliments for the contruction

loans.name: Melma

texts.en:
“No work, no food!” is a very simple expression shared by Melma P. who is a food vendor in the village of Bonfal proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcya. She aimed to improve their status of living so that she can give their children a better future by sending them to school. 

Her husband Leodigario is working as a driver of a passenger tricycle. Lita on the other hand is patiently cooking foods to retail in her food vending stall in front of their house. Having been maintained the business is a great help said Melma. However, because she wanted the business to further improve, she is asking for loan from the KVIA lenders amounting to PHP17, 000 as added business capital so that she will able to increase her income and be productive in the business.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita R. is from the village of Gumbil, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Teresita joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in future. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her seventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Vencie Marie

texts.en:
Vencie Marie S. is from the village of Brgy. 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Vencie Marie owns and operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling products such as slippers, sandals, handkerchiefs, hair accessories and other items, in the local community. Vencie Marie has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vencie Marie joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vencie Marie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
“Exert more efforts and have more patience to survive in the midst of crisis” said Marites F. of Barangay Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Alejandro and they were blessed with four children who are now studying in the elementary level. They wanted them to finish their studies so that they will not follow their poor living experiences.  

Despite of the hardships of life, Marites remains strong and continuous in persevering for the betterment of her family living. Farming is their primary source of income, they till their land twice a year by planting rice and some vegetables. Furthermore, Marites is engaged in the buy and sell business of coconut in their village. She wanted to borrow loan from KIVA lenders for the maintenance of her business.  She hopes to avail the amount of PHP10, 000 as additional business capital for she believes that this amount will make a way for business improvement.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Herm

texts.en: Herm H. is married with two children. He lives with his wife (pictured) in Battambong Province Province. To make a living, he is engaged in the construction business as a construction foreman, typically earning US $5 per day which is the primary source of income for his family. His wife is involved in a business of selling vegetable in a local market, earning an income of US $3 per day. Both of them have to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for the family and the children. Therefore, Phanna is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase various kinds of vegetable to expand her inventory.

loans.use: buy vegetable

loans.name: Dennis

texts.en:
Dennis is 27 years old and married to Ginalyn. He is a bread vendor in their village, and mainly sells pandesal, a bread famous in the country. Aside from selling pandesal, Dennis would like to buy additional baked breads and pastries to further increase his income. He also works as a part-time driver to meet the needs of his family, and is doing his best to lift his family out of poverty.

Dennis is requesting additional business capital of 4,000 PHP. In his daily vending routine, Dennis is able to sustain the needs of his family with his daily income of 200 PHP. With the loan he is taking from Kiva lenders, Dennis hopes to improve his bread-vending business. One day, he dreams of having his own baker's shop.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Richel Mae

texts.en:
Richel Mae D. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old and single. To make a living, Richel Mae owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Richel Mae has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,666 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Richel Mae joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Richel Mae has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Richel Mae is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her third from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila A. is from the village of San Antonio, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old, widowed and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Sheila owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling used clothing ("ukay-ukay") and doormats in the local community. Sheila has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Sheila joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheila is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily is a vegetable vendor in the village of Old Centro, San Mateo, Isabela. She is blessed with four children whom she supports with her daily income from vegetable selling. Her eldest child is Arthur, a 27-year-old high school graduate; then there is Khim, a 21-year-old college graduate; Alily, a 19-year-old who has just finished her two-year course; and Cris, an 18-year-old criminology student.

Lily wants her children to have a good future and she supports them in their dreams and ambitions. She believes that through her planting and selling of different vegetables, she can enable them to be what they want to be. In this regard, she would like to ask for financial support of 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to buy more kinds of vegetables to sell in the villages and also to maintain her vegetable garden from which she gets some of her products.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell and to maintain her vegetable garden

loans.name: Leout

texts.en: Leout S. is married with a young child. He lives with her wife (pictured) in Battambong Province Province. To make a living, he is employed as a builder at a construction site in the town, typically earning US $2.5 per day. His wife in engaged in the agriculture sector of growing vegetable, earning an income of US $1 per day. Both of them have to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for the family and the child. Therefore, S. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to easily commute to work and cut down great expenses on public transportation.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena G. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Lucena owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Lucena has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Lucena joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lucena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her fifth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is engaged in hog raising business. She believes that managing the business is of big help towards the fulfillment of her family goals in life. She is already 34 years old and is married to Eddie M. Sr. They are living in the simple village of Old Centro 1 San Mateo, Isabela. The couple is blessed with two children who are Eddie M. Jr., nine years old who is now in grade IV and Earl Tristan, five years old. The couple is doing everything to further supply all the needs of their children.

According to her, she needed additional capital for the needed feeds supplies of her hog raising business. Vilma hopes that she could buy a stock of feeds for the daily foods of her livestock. On this regard, she would like to avail a loan amounting PHP5, 000 from KIVA lenders for the business maintenance and further development. She really hopes that she could avail the loan amount she is requesting for her to generate bigger income as her children also grows same with their daily necessities in life.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Irina

texts.en: Irina is divorced and has one son. She owns a small business and sells clothing at central market in Novomoskovsk. Irina has been in this business for 15 years. She has always offered high quality products and client service. Today she has got many repeated clients and a stable business. Irina has active life position that encourages the business neighbors and friends. Irina would like to borrow 16,400 UAH to increase the inventories. She hopes to increase the sales and received additional income.

loans.use: to increase the inventories

loans.name: Nehemiah

texts.en:
Nehemiah is 44 years old and married to Evelyn, his business partner. They live in Rizaluna Cordon, Isabela, and are blessed with ten children. Nehemiah and Evelyn help each other to support their large family. Nehemiah manages a buy and sell vegetable business, and does his best to meet his family's needs through the income he generates from the business. Due to the growing needs of their family, Nehemiah noted that he needed to double his income. To have additional capital, Nehemiah is asking Kiva lenders for a loan of 5,000 PHP in order to improve his business and eventually increase his daily income.

Nehemiah has a strong determination to fulfill his dreams in life. He wants to be able to improve his family's poor way of living by improving and expanding his business.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Ek

texts.en: Ek S. is married with two young children. He lives with wife (pictured) in Batambong Province. Ek is currently employed as a security guard in a private security company, typically earning $4 USD per day. His wife is hired to prepare packages of fish meat, which is a kind of popular food in Batambong Province. She is able to earn an income of $2 USD per day from this work. Both of them have to work hard every day to ensure a good living for their family and children. Therefore, Ek S. is seeking to increase his income and improve his business. He is asking for a loan of $1200 USD to purchase various kinds of groceries and beverages for his wife to sell at his workplace.

loans.use: To buy groceries and beverages for resale

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en: Melanie L. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 20 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Melanie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anatolia

texts.en: A brave mother to her 6 siblings is Mrs. Anatolia L., 57 years of age, widow and a resident of Purok 3 Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She engaged in sari-sari store business to support her siblings especially she is now the bread winner to her family. She opened this kind of business 4 years ago. Mostly her customers are her neighbors in that area. She is now earning an average net income of not less than P3,000.00. She joined PAGLAUM MPC under the PDP-LP Program last July 2008 because she is interested with our programs and services especially in our insurances and savings. She is now a 4th cycle loaner and applying an amount of P10,000.00 to add her capital to her existing sari-sari store business. She is very happy that she is an active member in our cooperative.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store business

location.town: P3 Sta. Cruz, Tangub City, Mindanao

loans.name: Marng

texts.en: Marng S., 37, is a widow and resides in Kompong Cham Province. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling groceries in her village, earning approximately an income of US $10 per day in revenue. She has to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for her family, and her standard of living is improved since she starts her current business. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase more various kinds of grocery to expand her inventory and to satisfy all of her clients’ need. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her children.

loans.use: buy groceries

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en: Rosario is already 58 years old. She is married to Charlie who works as a farmer  old. They are gifted with five children and her youngest daughter is still studying. Rosario is dreaming to have additional income to continuously support her child needs in school to finish her studies. She is requesting to borrow loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5, 000 to further buy at least three sacks of rice to retail in her vending stall. Rosario is hoping that someday, she will sustain her business to give her family with a stable source of income.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Moudjibatou

texts.fr: E. Moudjibatou est née le 13/06/1959 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Moudjibatou est mariée à LAWANI Affissou Lay, un commerçant. Ce couple a à sa charge cinq enfants dont quatre sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis quatre ans à Donatin, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Moudjibatou vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Moudjibatou vend des bijoux en gros à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. C’est en CHINE que Moudjibatou va acheter ses bijoux. Moudjibatou a déjà trois ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Moudjibatou a déjà eu trois crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Moudjibatou demande un quatrième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
E. Moudjibatou was born on March 13, 1959 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin.  She is married to LAWANI Affissou Lay, a shopkeeper.  This couple has five children to support.  Four of them are their own.  For four years, the family has been residing in Donatin, a district of Cotonou.  Thanks to the income from her business, Moudjibatou comes to her husband's aid in covering family expenses.  Moudjibatou sells jewelry wholesale at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace in Benin.  She goes to China to purchase her jewelry.  She already has three years of experience in this business.  She had three loans with ALIDé before and has repaid them.  She was able to use them to raise her level of business.  To continue to develop her business, Moudjibatou is asking for a fourth loan to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewelry

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
Girlie is 22 years old, is married and has two kids. She lives in the rural community of Barangay Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She and her husband don’t have stable jobs but they are doing their best to earn a living to support the needs of their family. They aim to give their children a better future so that they will be the ones to help them when they got old.

Girlie and her husband help each other to earn a living. They are engaged in a business buying and selling fresh chicken and they are using their tricycle to deliver their products. Since they have inadequate capital, Girlie is asking for financial support of PHP 17,000 from Kiva lenders to improve their business.

Girlie also hopes to have her own selling stall where customers go to buy the fresh chicken she sells. Her income in the business provides her family with their daily basic commodities and enables them save some small amounts for the education of their future children.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Carmelino

texts.en:
Carmelino J. is from the village of San Antonio, Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 37 years old. Carmelino is married and has 4 school-aged children. Carmelino owns & operates a business cutting trees or logging. Carmelino has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Carmelino joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to engage in business activities. Carmelino is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to be used towards the purchase of materials needed to for his business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Carmelino from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tree-cutting materials for business.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam N., 33, is married and resides in Kompong Cham Province. She lives with her husband and her two young children. She is engaged in a business of selling various kinds of groceries in the village, earning an income of US $15 in revenue per day. Her husband is involved in the agriculture business of growing vegetable on his plot of farmland, earning approximately an income of US $5 per day. Their family standard of living has been improved a lot since they operate these businesses. Therefore, N. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase more groceries to expand her current business. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to raise a good living for her family because of this proper business plan.

loans.use: buy groceries

loans.name: Vey

texts.en: Vey N., 25, is married and resides in Kompong Cham Province. She lives with her husband and her young child in a way simple way of life. To make a living, she is engaged in the business of selling gasoline in front of her house in the village, earning an approximate income of US $5 per day. The family is supported financially primarily by her husband, who operates as a taxi driver using his own car. He provides a taxi service from the province to the city, earning an income of US $15 per day. These businesses have made the family’s standard of living much better. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase various kinds of groceries to start a new business. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to raise the good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To buy groceries to open a grocery store.

loans.name: Max

texts.en:
Max F. is applying for a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000 as additional working capital for the maintenance of his duck raising business. He operates this busines in the village of San Juan Quezon, Isabela where his family also lives. At his age of 43, Max remains single and he has been very dedicated towards the development of his business. 

He hopes to improve his business and to give enough support towards the needs of his family, especially his parents. By working hard and with patience, Max believes that someday or somehow he can able to make himself successful with the continuous assistance of lenders to his business.

loans.use: Towards additional business capital.

loans.name: Ul

texts.en: Ul C., 46, is married and resides in Kompong Cham Province. She makes her simple living in the agriculture sector as a rice field farmer on her own plot of farmland. She earns an income of approximately US $1.70 per day. Her husband is a teacher in a local school in the village, and he spends his time away from teaching by charging batteries with a generator that he owns. He is able to earn an income of US $7.50 per day as a primary source of income for the family. The family is also assisted by the two children who are now growing crops and involved in a local bakery shop. These businesses have made the standard of living for the family improve. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase a bakery machine and a motorbike. By doing so, the family will have a new business and cut down expenses on public transportation.

loans.use: To buy a bakery machine.

loans.name: Nita

texts.en:
Nita B. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Nita is married and has 4 school-aged children. Nita owns & operates a business selling fruits and vegetable products in the local community. Nita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Nita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Nita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
“Try and try until you succeed” is the guiding principle of Milagros M. from the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She have four children who are studying in the tertiary and secondary level of education. She is a responsible mother to them and wishing them their success in the future. They wanted them to become successful in their chosen career so that they will have a bright future in return.

In this regard, she and her husband Benjamin are helping one other to earn a living and support the education of their children. They cultivate their farm by planting rice and vegetables. Furthermore, Milagros is engaged in selling dried fish and fish sauce in their village through house to house delivery. She is borrowing additional business capital of PHP18, 000 that will be used in the development of her vending business. According to her, because of patience, she is able to generate the amount of PHP900 weekly income from her business. Her business income is really of big help to the needs of her family. She hopes to improve the loan she is borrowing by investing into the development of her selling business.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn N. is from the village of Bongabong,Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Emelyn is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Emelyn owns & operates a business selling soft drinks in the local community. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,050.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Emelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Emelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emelyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to be used to purchase additional inventory & towards working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Emelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Towards working capital and to purchase inventory.

loans.name: But

texts.en: But S., 31, is married and resides in Kompong Cham Province. She is engaged in the agriculture sector of growing few types of vegetable to serve the market’s need. She is able to earn an income of US $0.7 per day. To make a living, her husband is employed as a worker at the market in his village with an income of US $2.5 per day. S. really wants to improve her living standard and generate more income for the future’s education of her children. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $300 to purchase fertilizer to make her crops grow efficiently. She hopes that her proper plan of expanding the outputs of the crop will help her to achieve the successful goal for the family.

loans.use: buy fertilizer

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl A. is a 39-year-old woman from Pasay City.  Her husband, Leonardo, 41, drives a pedicab (rickshaw) for a living.  They have an only child who is still at home. They live among the city’s poorest communities.

Cheryl has had a small general store for more than two years. She saved most of her earnings until she was able to purchase the pedicab that her husband now uses in his business. Cheryl earns PHP9,000.00 a month. She uses her profits to address daily basic needs.  

Cheryl became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She has applied for a new loan (PHP10,000.00) in order to increase the inventory of groceries for her store.

It has always been her intention to send her child to college. This is why she has been working hard day and night.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en: Olga is married with two children. She sells fresh fish. Olga started this business about a year ago. At that time she bought a small truck of fish and was able to sell it just in one day! Since then she has been buying fresh fish in bulk and selling it in her city. Olga would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to purchase big vessels for fish. Olga is very enthusiastic person and would like to develop her small business further.

loans.use: to purchase business equipment

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma A. is from the village of Punta. She is 56 years old. Norma is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Norma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years with an approximate average monthly earnings of 6,000 PHP for these activities.

In 2008, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Norma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to venture another business such as selling ready-to-wear clothes and dried fish in addition to her farming activity. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Norma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to venture another business

loans.name: Yourng

texts.en: Yourng H., 62, is married and resides with her husband in Kompong Cham Province. To make a living, she sells Cambodian noodle in front her house in the village, earning an income of US $2 per day. Her husband is construction worker who has to travel from places to places in the province to find work, earning an income of US $5 per day which is the primary source of income for the family. The family is also assisted by her two children who are currently involved with the same job to his father in the city, earning a reasonable income to make a living and to aid the family. H. really wants to take a loan of US $600 to buy supplements such as woods for her husband to help improve his work and to generate a better income.

loans.use: buy suppliments for the construction

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina said that managing such business needed enough patience and hard works to achieve success in life. She is happily married to Samuel S. who is tricycle driver. The couple strives for their best to earn money for their three children. As of now, her three children are studying and they are in their different level of education. Cristina and Samuel hopes that their three children will someday finish their schooling through sufficient financial support coming from their tricycle transport daily income. 

In this regard, Cristina is requesting to avail the amount of PHP4, 000 as capital for the maintenance of their motor vehicle for transport. She also would like to venture in vending to further help her husband earn for their daily living. Despite of the difficulties in their lives, this couple is doing their best to sustain the needs of their family particularly their children’s educational needs.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Puth

texts.en: Puth H., 48, is married and resides with her husband and their 16-year-old child in Kompong Cham province. To make a living, she is engaged in a business selling Cambodian traditional cakes. She also raises pigs at her home in the village, earning an income of US $3 per day. Her husband is involved in the agriculture sector as rice field farmer in the flooding area of his farmlands, earning an income of US $2 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since they start these businesses. H. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase pig feed. By doing so, her pigs will grow up efficiently and she will then be able to sell the pigs at a good price.

loans.use: To buy pig feed.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is engaged in the hog raising business. He also drives a van transport for him to generate additional income for the maintenance of his hog raising business and to meet the immediate needs of his family. Vincent is happily married to Jesusa. The couple is blessed with two children who were King James - 19 years old and John Michael - 18 years old. The couple is doing all their best to raise their children well and somehow give them education for their future jobs. 

Vincent is asking for loan amounting to PHP5, 000 as added business capital to his hog raising. He wanted to supply his livestock with enough feeds for their foods daily. He believes that through the said business, his family, especially the education of his children will be sustained. In this regard, Vincent is working hard and patiently doing his best to become successful in the business someday.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lorna B. is from the village of Labo, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Lorna is married and has 2 adult children. Lorna owns & operates a "sari-sari" store where she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2004, Lorna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP to be used to purchase additional inventory & towards working capital. This will be the 18th loan taken out by Lorna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & increase working capital.

loans.name: Arn

texts.en: Arn P., 37, is married and has 3 school-aged children. She resides with her husband in Kompong Cham Province. P. is engaged in the business of selling Cambodian noodles in front of her house, earning US $2.5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker in the nearby place of the province, earning an income of US $5 per day. Her husband’s income is the primary source of support for the family. P. really wants to take a loan of US $500 to purchase a mechanical plow for her husband to start another business of transporting rice from the local villagers at the fields for a better income.

loans.use: To buy a mechanical plow.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida H. is from the village of Gumbil,Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Nida is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Nida owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Nida has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 4,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Nida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Nida is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is a vendor of native cakes that she personally cooks.  She is 45 years old and married with three children.  They are living in the village of Old Centro 1 San Mateo, Isabela. Dolores would like to improve their way of living and she wants her three children to finish their third level of education. Her eldest is Andreo - 21 years old, fourth year college, taking up criminology; Ryan - 20 years old, fourth year high school, and Wowee Roy - 11 years old, sixth grade student. 

Dolores is asking for financial support amounting to PHP5,000 that will be used as working capital for her snack vending business in their village. She lacks capital and is praying for the approval of her loan request from Kiva lenders. Dolores is also hoping that, through her vending business, her family will be uplifted from their poor living situation.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena A. is from the village of Aloran. She is 47 years old. Lucena is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lucena owns & operates a "sari-sari" store business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lucena has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lucena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Lucena is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Lucena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gildo

texts.en: Gildo is 32 years old and is still single. He also serves as treasurer officer in their Barangay while at the same time managing his general store business. He is requesting to borrow loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5, 000 as additional business capital. He would also like to expand his business into cell phone load retailing to further increase his daily income. With the amount of loan he hopes to avail, Gildo believes that his business will somehow become progressive by utilizing it wisely. Gildo is from the village of San Juan Quezon, Isabela. He hopes to give his future family a better living someday by his continuous maintenance in the business.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Fredelina

texts.en: Fredelina is 42 years old and she is married to Benjamin. They both manages their tricycle transport business. The couple is blessed with five children; two of them are already married. They are hoping that they could be able to provide for the education of their three left children in their house. Fredelina wanted their motorcycle to be repaired, changes some of its spare parts. In this regard, she wanted to request for a loan amounting to PHP4, 000 from the KIVA lenders for the repair and maintenance of their motorcycle since they don’t have enough money for the said purpose. Furthermore, Fredelian shared that having their motorcycle used in transport business is a big help in providing their daily immediate needs and allowances of their children to school. These are the reason why, she wanted their motorcycle be maintained for it is where they get their daily source of income.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
Jesus A. is from the village of Brgy. 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 59 years old. Jesus is married and has two grown children. To make a living, Jesus owns and operates a furniture-making business.  He makes and sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Jesus has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jesus joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jesus is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of his family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making additional furniture

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en: Mrs. Kheng K. lives in Thlork village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Nou Sokha, is a motorbike taxi driver. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income to support their household. Thus, Mrs. Kheng K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn more income. She is 43 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn more income.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Production of vegetables is the business that Rosalinda M. ventured in. With the assistance of her husband Orlando who is a vendor of charcoal, Rosalinda is able to implement her vegetable production and vending. The couple is thankful because they have been blessed with a boy named Orly, he is now 16 years old and is currently studying. Being a good couple, they are doing their best to give their son a good future by continuously sending him to school and someday earn a degree. 

Rosalinda hopes that she could supply sufficient needs of her family. She works hard to double the income she generates. According to her, she also would like to have her business grow and this will be pursued if she could have enough business capital. For this reason, she then applied for loan from KIVa lenders amounting to PHP4, 000. She hopes that lenders will allow her borrow the amount requested.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en: Valentina is a widow and her children have grown up and moved out. Valentina sells clothing at the market in Kherson city and has a very good location that brings many clients her way. Her business does well. Valentina has been in this business for nine years, ever since she saw that women's clothing is one of the few products that sell well and produce a stable income. Valentina would like a loan of 9,000 UAH to add to the assortment of clothing she sells. She would spend any additional income to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase her assortment of clothing

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is about to start her general store business however, she has only a limited capital to utilized. For this reason, she wanted to apply for loan from KIVa lenders amounting to PHP4, 000 as start up capital to further pursue her planned store. She is happily married to Dante and they live happily in Barangay Rizaluna Cordon, Isabela. The couple is blessed with three children namely Edison – nine years old is now in grade-IV; Disyrene - four years old and Devorah - 11 months old. 

Evelyn plans to purchase different merchandise for her store.  She hopes that KIVA lenders will lend her the capital she needed to begin in the business. She really wanted to help for the progress of her family living by doing such business that would be a daily income generating one. Evelyn is praying that soon, lenders will give her the chance.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Maria Cecilia

texts.en:
Maria Cecilia B., 38, is in on the grassroots level of the I.T. industry.  She hails from Amadeo, a town in Cavite province, famous for its aromatic coffee.  Her husband Gilmore, 50, is a police officer.  They have three children.

Maria Cecilia owns and manages a computer shop located in downtown Amadeo.  Her computer shop is relatively new, as she just opened last year, but it has shown promising results.  She caters to students attending a nearby school.  She now earns approximately $200 a month.  Her profits are enough to sustain her family’s needs, especially her children’s education.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative just this year but the loans provided by the cooperative have already been very helpful in the growth of her business.  She was able to buy more computer units for her shop.

Maria Cecilia has applied for a new loan from the cooperative in the amount of P8,000.00.  She will use the funds to buy an additional computer unit.  She hopes to furnish her shop with at least ten personal computers to address the growing demands of customers.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy another computer unit for her shop

loans.name: Idermunkh

texts.en: Idermunkh is 35 years old and lives with his wife and nine-year-old son in the Uyurkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Idermunkh’s wife operates a mobile retail clothing business while Idermunkh owns and manages his housing and furniture business.  He began his business in 2003 by making only the wooden walls for gers. He soon partnered with his friend, Ganzorig, and they expanded the product line to include furniture as well.  The business has been so successful that Idermunkh purchased a truck which allows him to deliver his products to his customers. Idermunkh would one day like to open a small factory in which he can produce even more products with ease.  He is requesting a 1,800,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more wood and supplies in order to expand his business and keep up with his customers’ orders.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and supplies

loans.name: Bayanbuu

texts.en: Bayanbuu is 27 years old and lives with his wife and one year old daughter in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city.  He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  His wife is currently working for the police academy as a secretary and their daughter stays at home. Bayanbuu not only takes care of his wife and daughter, but he is also responsible for his mother and terminally ill younger brother. After saving money from his previous job, Bayanbuu purchased a car which enabled him to start his own transportation business in 2008.  During the last year, he has saved enough money to purchase a microbus which has enabled him to transport more people and goods. Bayanbuu is committed to not only improving the lives of his wife and child, but he is also committed to making sure that his brother has the best care possible. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to buy a newer, more reliable microbus so that his business will become even more profitable.

loans.use: to buy a newer, more reliable mini bus

loans.name: Dorjpurev

texts.en: Dorjpurev is 55 years old and lives with his wife and youngest daughter in Uyurkhangai province in Mongolia.  He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  A father of three, Dorjpurev is supporting his youngest daughter while she attends university while the other two children live and work in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Dorjpurev is a craftsman of wooden products, specifically gers and ger furniture.  He started his business in 2004, and has grown it since then.  The summer and fall months are particularly busy for Dorjpurev, because of wedding season, but the winter and spring are slower. He would like to expand his product line to include different types of wooden products so that he can attract more customers during those winter and spring months.  He is requesting a 430,000 tugrug (~300 USD) loan to purchase more wood and supplies for his business.

loans.use: to purchase more wood and supplies

loans.name: Demetrio

texts.en: Demetrio S. manages a furniture shop. Demetrio makes sala sets, cabinets, wooden tables and other house and office furniture. He is 42 years of age and married to Sharlyn, a housewife. Managing this business is very helpful in sending their children to school. For many years, Demetrio has never lost hope in trying to improve his business, though he has usually failed because of his life's difficulties and lack of financial capital. Thus, he wants to borrow 5,000 PHP from KIVA lenders. He knows that using the money wisely will lead to better business opportunities in the future.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Enkhtaivan

texts.en:
Enkhtaivan produces the inner and outer coverings for gers (traditional Mongolian nomadic tents). Enkhtaivan’s ger covering business has been so successful that, not only does she support her daughter and parents, she has also been able to attend two years of business school. Before she started her ger covering business, she and her sister began by making deels (traditional Mongolian clothing) in 2000. The success of that business enabled her to begin her own business several years later.

Enkhtaivan is a 35 year old single mother who lives with her parents and young daughter in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. The family lives together in a ger. She is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~420 USD) loan to purchase supplies and tools for her business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and tools

loans.name: Ayidédji Justine

texts.fr: C. Ayidédji Justine est née vers 1955 à Akpro Missérété. Ayidédji Justine est veuve. Ayidédji Justine a à sa charge trois enfants dont deux sont les tiens. La famille réside depuis deux ans à Sèmè Kpodji. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Ayidédji Justine arrive à satisfaire ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants. Ayidédji Justine vend des beignets de haricot, de l’igname et de pomme frits. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Ayidédji Justine fait ses provisions et elle vend ses beignets et igname au parc MIVO. Ayidédji Justine a déjà deux ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Ayidédji Justine a eu quatre crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Ayidédji Justine demande un cinquième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de haricot, d’igname, de l’huile d’arachide et des condiments.

loans.name: Dudu

texts.en:
Dudu A. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and onions and is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil to sell. Dudu is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has four children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Hog raising is the chosen business wants to manage by Flordeliza N.. She is asking to avail the amount of PHP5, 000 from the KIVA lenders for the maintenance of her business. She hopes also to improve her hog raising activity with the financial assistance of the lenders and be able to give her children a good future by sending them to school. 

Flordeliza is from the village of San Juan Quezon, Isabela. She has four children and she is married to Domingo N. who is a farmer. Managing her hog raising business is already of big help to her husband providing their family necessities. They help each other in providing the financial needs of their children as they are pursuing their studies. She hopes that someday, with their hard works and perseverance, they will not just provide their children education but also sustain their livelihood for their future use.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Meas' Group

texts.en: S. is a group leader of three members, she is teacher of primary school. She lives in thatch roof house alone next to her group members houses. Besides her work, she trade another small daily activity as a rice middle trader from the village to to market sell. She is taking a loan to invest in her rice middle trade for a more income. The other two members are Y. and L. all of them two are the traditional cake sellers.

loans.use: to invest in her rice middle trade for a more income

loans.name: Therese

texts.en:
Marie Therese Dusabemariya is 45 years old, married with 3 children aged between 15 and 3 years old.

Marie Therese has an experience of 5 years in selling fruits by working from 8h00 A.M to 6h00 P.M.  Therese is getting not much profit to help her to be economically independent, it’s for that reason that she is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a for expanding her business though buying more fruits for sale.

Through accessing this new loan,  Therese hopes to see her life changing and she will be able to save for the future.

loans.use: for purchasing more fruits for sale

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia B., a 50-year-old vendor from Pasay City, has been selling golf balls in front of the golf course where her husband works. She earns 10,000 PHP a month, but sales are low on rainy days because players will not play on a muddy driving range. Her husband, Constantino, 51, works as a caddy at the golf course. They have two adult children. Nelia sets up a plastic table to sell her items every day. She has been in this business for the last five years.

Nelia became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She is now on her thirteenth loan cycle with the cooperative. Nelia is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP as additional capital for her business. It has always been her desire to have a happy family in spite of living in poor conditions.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: For additional business capital

loans.name: Bayaraa

texts.en: Bayaraa is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the Arkhangai province in Mongolia.  He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  Bayaraa and his wife own a raw material, such as sheep skin and wool trading business in their town where they buy raw materials locally and sell the materials in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, for a profit.  He started his business in 2000 with working capital of 150,000 tugrugs (~100 USD) which soon grew to 4,500,000 tugrugs (~3160 USD). Bayaraa has gained a lot of experience and knowledge over the years and he hopes to use this experience and knowledge to keep his business growing. He would like to, one day, own his own store where he can sell the raw materials and expand his customer base.  Bayaraa is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to purchase more raw materials in order to increase sales.

loans.use: to purchase more raw materials

loans.name: Ijok

texts.en:
Ijok S. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and rice to sell.  Ijok is 36 years old and is Married with a husband that is a police man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia G., 56, may have lost almost all of her family’s precious belongings in a fire that razed their village in the middle of a shanty town in Pasay City in 2007, but she did not lose faith. She was able to “rise from the ashes” together with her three children.

Lucia has a general store which had been growing steadily over the years. Then she was challenged when one of her children was afflicted by a crippling cerebral palsy. She was in great emotional pain. Medical expenses took a heavy toll on their finances. Just when she was almost adjusted to their situation, the fire razed their village. Picking up her life’s pieces, Lucia re-established her general store just after the fire (the same year she joined the Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative). Perseverance paid off and she is now earning 24,000 PHP a month. She is using her profits to gradually renovate their house and support her children’s education as well.

Lucia is now asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP as additional capital for her business. She will also use a portion of the fund to continue the renovations on her house.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: For business expansion and home renovation

loans.name: Kaku

texts.en:
Kaku V. is currently in the business of selling books at the bookshop and is requesting a loan to purchase more texts and exercise books to sell. 

 Kaku is 26 years old and is Married with a husband that is a professional secondary teacher. She has 2 children and her children go to school. 

 With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a printing press.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more texts and exercise books to sell

loans.name: Arlina

texts.en:
Arlina M. is selling different goods and some food in her vending stall at Barangay San Juan Quezon, Isabela where her family happily lives. Her vending stall is within the vicinity of the elementary school in their village. Children who are attending their elementary grades are her common customers in the business. Her desire to give her family with a progressive living is motivating Arlina to work harder towards the improvement of her business so that she will able to generate bigger income. In this regard, she is applying for loan to have additional business capital. She hopes to borrow from KIVA lenders the amount of PHP3, 000. 

Arlina is married to Pepito M. who is a farmer. They are blessed with three children namely; Efren, Jeferson, and Prixeljoy. Her income from the business is use to add some items to sell in her canteen. Her dream is to grow her business to continue sending and supporting her children needs in school.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Vilginie

texts.en:
Vilginie U. is 27 years old and is married with three children aged between 9 and 4. She lives in Musanze District, Ruhengeli Province, where she has sold clothes in the market since 1997. Vilginie operates her business every day from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

Vilginie is requesting her second loan from Vision Finance Company in order to earn more profit; after earning more profit she will be able to save money in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Furu

texts.en: Furu D. is currently in the business of selling fruits such as: mangoes, oranges etc and is requesting a loan to purchase green vegetables to sell.  Furu is 40 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase green vegetables to sell

loans.name: Dovi Tawiah

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de friperie dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé ; cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans le foyer pour l’éducation scolaire de leurs 03 enfants. Elle a débuté ce commerce en 2003 et s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé à l’ouverture des bals de friperie. Elle a loué une place dans le marché où elle est bien connue de beaucoup de clients qui lui sont restés fidèles. Elle vend des vêtements pour dames et enfants ; actuellement elle a besoin de disposer d’un nouveau stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 03 bals de friperie
texts.en:
This woman has a revenue generating business, selling second-hand clothing in the market of Hédzranawoé, in the city of Lomé. This business enables her to pay for her 3 children's school tuition. She started her business in 2003 and supplies herself with goods from the big market in Lomé at the opening of bales of second-hand clothing.
