For about four years now, Esther has run a business selling foodstuffs from a table. With the income, she caters to her children and supports them in school. Her challenge has been a lack of finance but she is successful in attracting her customers by providing for their needs with reasonable and affordable prices. She dreams of a bigger business to adequately support her kids.

loans.use: To buy additional foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Animonyam Group

texts.en:
David is 55 years old he is married with eight children. Currently seven children are in school. He is a chemical seller and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonic, pain killers, malaria drugs etc. in his neighborhood. He has been in business for six years now and he is among the people who supply pharmaceutical products in the community. His chemical shop is registered to operate by Ghana pharmaceutical council. He wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of drugs to include others that are frequently demanded by his customers. He hopes to raise good income to take care of his family. He would be grateful for your assistance.

He is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Animonyam’ which literary means God’s glory. He is the one sitting in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers etc. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of pharmaceutical drugs.

loans.name: Johnson  Street Business Center Group

texts.en:
The Johnson Street Business Center is a group of five borrowers led by Augustine S., who is 56 years old and married with seven children. The children are between the ages of 8 and 31 years old. The younger ones are in school. Augustine also cares for five siblings. Augustine is a high-school graduate and a trade certificate holder. 

Augustine lives and sells on Johnson Street, a business community close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. Augustine's business is in construction wood. He buys it at wholesale prices and sells at retail. He has been running this business for five years. He believes that offering good prices and providing strong customer service have allowed him to come this far.

Augustine believes strongly in his business and wishes to improve it to a higher level. He is requesting this loan to purchase more wood for sale so as to acquire more profit. He dreams of giving his family a better education as a means of preparing them for the future.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for sale

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan Karinga is 29 years old, married and she takes care of one kid of 7 months old.

Joan has been in a business of selling various hardware parts for the past two years working from 7h00A.M to 6 h00P.M. After realizing that his investment is too low to get more profit, he is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company s.a for the purpose of expanding her business through buying many products.

By receiving this new loan, Joan plans to help her husband to buy a house and save for the future of his family.

loans.use: purchasing more merchandises

loans.name: Walo Group

texts.en:
In the New Foyah community, Market area, Foyah District, Lofa County, Finda lives with her four children whose ages range between 11 and 24 years, with education levels up to college.

Finda has sold dry goods and clothes for about three years now from whence she caters to her children and supports them in school. Her challenge has been the lack of finance but she is successful in attracting her customers by words of encouragement and by offering affordable prices. She dreams of owning a bigger business to adequately support her kids.

loans.use: To buy additional dry goods, adult and children's clothes, etc.

loans.name: Amor Y Paz 4 Group

texts.en:
Olga C. is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the group coordinator for Amor y Paz 1 (Love and Peace), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in her group.

Olga (Pictured: center) is 55 years old and lives with her husband and two boys, an 11-year-old and a 19-year-old. They live in Batey Caimito, a beautiful community in the hills of the east-central region of the Dominican Republic. A batey is a community of sugarcane field workers in the rural areas of the Dominican Republic. Bateyes are very remote, hard to access, and most people live in deep poverty. They often lack potable water, medicine, and any kind of reliable electricity.

In order to feed her family and send her children to school, Olga sells used clothing to her community. Typically, packs of used clothes will arrive from the United States, and Olga will buy them to sell for a profit. She will also use this loan to purchase charcoal, a valuable commodity in a community without reliable electricity. 

Olga hopes that she will be able to send her two boys to university, giving them a step up in society. One will soon be done with high school, and the other is just entering middle school. This is Olga’s fourth loan with Esperanza, and she has a perfect repayment record! Thank you for lending to Olga and the Amor y Paz group!

loans.use: Used clothes and charcoal

loans.name: Claudia  Marina

texts.es: Claudia  Marina  R.  D. F. resiD. en el municipio D. Apopa del departamento D. San Salvador. Claudia tiene 46 años D. edad  vive con su mamá María D. 70 años, su hija D. 23 años D. edad y la nieta D. 6 años, Claudia posee su propio negocio un  comedor y pupuseria ubicado frente a una escuela D. la zona, el negocio D. Claudia es el preferido D. muchos por su amabilidad y los deliciosos licuados que caracterizan su negocio. Claudia solicita un crédito para compra insumos necesarios que le permitan aumentar su producción.

loans.use: compra de insumos para aumentar producción

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a 38-year-old divorced woman with two children. Both of her children are students at the community-built school. Life, she says, is challenging, but she tries hard to overcome life's obstacles with the help of God.

She is currently in the business of selling earrings and necklaces made of silver, copper, and gold, which she sells through hawking in the market. In addition, she recently started selling body powder -- powder that she produces by herself. She is able to combine the two businesses with the help of her six-year-old daughter, who helps with the businesses when she gets out of school.

Sophia purchases goods and materials from Kumasi, and then she sells her stock to her customers. She is requesting a loan to buy earrings and necklaces, as well as raw (body powder) materials, to upgrade her inventory. Ultimately, she wants to help her children continue with their education, and she will use the loan proceeds to further expand her businesses.

loans.use: To expand her businesses by purchasing assorted earrings and necklaces in bulk, as well as raw materials for body powder

loans.name: Lis Helen

texts.es: Lis Helen F. G. reside en Ciudad Delgado municipio del departamento de San Salvador. Lis tiene 26 años de edad se encuentra recién casada con Jose. Juntos han montado un negocio el cual es atendido por Lis,  ya que Jose sale a trabajar fuera de casa. El negocio es un ciber café y una pequeña librería, Lis solicita este crédito para comprar mayores productos para su librería lo que le ayudara a fortalecer su negocio al igual que sus ventas.

loans.use: Para surtir su negocio

loans.name: Justice

texts.en:
Justice is 41 years old he is married with four children. Currently all his children are in school. He is a chemical seller and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonic, pain killers, malaria drugs etc. in his neighborhood. He has added the sale of agro-chemicals products that are used in a farm inputs to his goods but it is separated from the consumable drugs to prevent danger on human health and the environment.

He has been in business for three years now and he is among the people who supply pharmaceutical products in the community. He wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of drugs to include others that are frequently demanded by his customers. He hopes to raise good income to take care of his family especially his children education. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of pharmaceutical drugs.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional clothing and charcoal for resale purposes

loans.name: Business Of Faith Group

texts.en:
Ever since her husband died in a motor accident, Watta has been a widow with 6 children. Her children are between the ages of 18 and 30 years old, and all of them have received high school-level education. And she notes that she has two orphans living with her family.

For the past eight years, she has been operating a business where she sells dry goods. By doing so, she is able to provide for her children and to send them to school. Her biggest challenge has been a lack of funding for her business, since she has always been very successful at attracting customers -- by catering to their needs with reasonable and affordable prices. She dreams of having a bigger business to better support her kids.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional dry goods (e.g., rice, oil, salt)

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is 32 years old she is married and mother with one child who is currently in school. She is a baker and bakes bread together with other pastries like meat pie etc. and supply to her loyal customers. For the past three years till now, she is been baking bread and other food pastries in taking care of her household. In spite of the challenges she faces she manages to handle demand of her customers and successfully meet their request on time. Her only problem now has to do with adequate funds to buy raw materials as prices are shooting up. She requests a loan support to remain in business. With the loan she believes she can provide for her family and save more for future eventuality. She said your help is much needed in her life and business.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast and firewood etc.

loans.name: Tuesendo Group

texts.en:
Ever since her husband died in a drowning accident, Finda has lived as a widow with seven children around the Chasenneh area, in the Foyah District of Lofa County. Her children range in age from 12 years old to 30 years old, and they generally have received 8th grade-level education.

For the past five years, she has been in the business of making pop, food, and soap. By doing so, she is able to provide for her children and to support them in school. She explains that her biggest challenge has been a lack of funding since she is rather successful at attracting customers with her reasonable/affordable prices. She dreams of operating a larger business in order to better support her kids.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional raw materials (e.g., rice, sugar, oil, and flour)

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta is 36years old she is married and mother of three children. All her children are in school in the community where they live. She is very hard working women and works to support the husband in taking care of the family. She trades in Ghana made slippers; she takes delivery of stock from Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She purchases them in different sizes, colors and designs so that her customers can make their choice. She mostly sells them through hawking that is house to house selling. She has no regret of this business because it has given her lots of experienced in marketing and sales. And this business also brings income to support her family. She requests for your loan assistance to buy stock in bulk. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy Ghana made slippers in Kumasi for retail.

loans.name: Marta Emilia

texts.es: Marta Emilia A. D. H. resiD. en Soyapango municipio del departamento D. San Salvador. Marta tiene 38 años D. edad vive con sus dos hijos D. 10 y 14 años D. edad, estudiantes y su esposo Carlos quien es Pastor D. una iglesia evangélica D. la zona D. Soyapango. Marta posee su propio negocio es una venta D. productos personales como perfumes y cremas, también venD. ropa; y si todo esto no fuese poco, Marta ahora ha montado una venta D. pupusas para poder generar mayores ingresos, el crédito que solicita Marta es para surtir su inventario D. productos y comprar harina para aumentar la producción D. sus pupusas.
texts.en:
Marta Emilia A. D. H. lives in the Soyapango municipality in the San Salvador department. Marta is 38, and she lives with her husband and two children. The children, ages 10 and 14, go to school. Her husband, Carlos, is a pastor in an evangelical church in the Soyapango region. Marta has her own business selling personal products like perfumes and creams. She also sells clothes. As if all that was not enough, Marta now sells “pupusas” (stuffed tortillas) to be able to generate more income. The loan that Marta is asking for is to stock her inventory of products and to buy flour to increase her production of pupusas.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business and buy supplies for "pupusas" (stuffed tortillas)

loans.name: Andrea Celeste

texts.es:
La señora Andrea vive con su novio y juntos tienen una hija, posee  casa propia en la ciudad de Piribebuy compañia Yrugua, en donde posee un pequeño establecimiento.
La señora Andrea empezó trabajando desde muy chiquita con sus padres en la actividad de tambo. Luego emprendió su propio tambo, empezó con una vaca que le regalaron sus padres,  de apoco fueron aumentando mas vacas productora de leche, y empezaron a elaborar queso, gracias a la calidad de sus productos rápidamente fue aumentando su clientela, y se sintieron obligados de aumentar su producción.
El crédito que solicita es para compra de otra vaca lechera y satisfacer de esta manera la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Andrea lives with her boyfriend and their daughter. She has her own house in the city of Piribebuy, Yrugua company (a district is divided into 23 companies). She has a small establishment there. When she was very little Andrea started working with her parents’ in their dairy farm. Then she started her own dairy farm. She started with one cow that her parents gave her. Soon there were more milking cows, and they started to make cheese. Thanks to the quality of her products, she got more customers. They felt obliged to increase their production. The loan she is asking for is to buy another milking cow to be able to meet her customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a milking cow for cheese production

loans.name: Business Friends Group

texts.en:
Kumba is a married woman with seven children. Her children range in age between 6 and 15 years old.

For the past 8 years, she has been operating a business where she sells oil goods. She notes that she has faced many challenges in recent years, both family problems and financial issues, but that she runs a successful business. She attributes her success to the fact that she is able to attract many customers by interacting with her customers and also by offering goods at reasonable/affordable prices. She hopes to improve her business in such a way that she will be able to better support her children.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional materials (e.g., tins and drums) for her oil sales business

loans.name: María Leonor

texts.es: María Leonor P. D. C.  D. 59 años D. edad, resiD. en Soyapango municipio del gran San Salvador. María vive su esposo y su única hija, Gabriela D. 19 años D. edad estudiante D. bachillerato. María posee su negocio desD. su casa, donD. su principal herramienta D. trabajo, es la maquina coser, María confecciona variedad D. ropa a la medida, el crédito que solita es para comprar tela y así poder fabricar camisas para ser vendidas con sus clientes, María ya ha manejado créditos los cuales ha pagado siendo muy puntual en sus pagos.
texts.en:
María Leonor P. D. C., 59, lives in the Soyapango municipality of the great San Salvador. María lives with her husband and their only daughter, Gabriela. Gabriela is 19, and she is studying for her bachelor’s degree. María has a business, which she runs from home. Her main work tool is her sewing machine. She makes a variety of custom maD. clothes. The loan she is asking for is to buy fabric in order to be able to make shirts to sell to her customers. María has managed loans. She has paid them back, and she was very punctual with her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric

loans.name: Dr. Jesus Group

texts.en:
Abena started her fish business a year and half ago in a community market where she lives. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty fish in the market and for that reason she is fun of many. She buys stocks of fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is 35years old widowed and mother with two children. All the children are in school. She supports her children from the business proceeds. She depends on that for their food, school bills and sometimes their medical bills. She demands the loan to buy increased stock of assorted fishes to make increased sales and income to support her children education and business growth. She hopes to repay the loan on time. She always tries to save part of her profit for future eventualities.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Dr. Jesus’. She is the one sitting in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, hardware sellers, food vendors etc. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fishes and dried fish.

loans.name: New Era Group

texts.en:
Siah N. and her fellow group members are from the Foyah Market area in the Foyah District of Lofa County. Siah lives with her two children, ages three and 14. Her older child is in ninth grade.

Siah sells items such as salt, onions, cubes, and manpo at market. She has done this for about three years now, and her business allows her to support her children and pay their school fees. Her primary challenge has been the lack of finances, but she is successful in attracting her customers by providing for their needs with reasonable and affordable prices.

She dreams of a bigger business so as to adequately support her kids.

loans.use: To buy additional goods such as salt, onions, cubes, and manpo to sell at market

loans.name: Waobendian Group

texts.en:
Gbolie is a 40-year-old illiterate widower with five children whose ages range from 2 to 20 years and whose level of education ranges up to college.

Gbolie has been involved in weaving (country-cloth-making) for about five years now. His challenge has been finances but he is successful in attracting more customers to his goods because of his styles and designs which could be classified as “the latest”.

Gbolie dreams of having a modern tailoring shop that will enable him to produce more to sell to the public and enable him to educate his children and assist them in other areas.

loans.use: To buy thread, cottons, needles and other materials

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 45-year-old single mother of five children aged between 16 and 24 years, four of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she lives with ten people. There is electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets one meal a day.

Sarah resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala on Rubaga Road and she works seven days a week. She sells local gin (alcohol) and serves at least twenty customers a day.

Sarah buys this local gin from suppliers, who get it from villages, and she uses public transport to and from shopping at Owino Market in Kafumbe Mukasa zone. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises.

Sarah sells to all categories of people and on both a retail and a wholesale basis. Prior to this business she was selling posho (also know as ugali - a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour).

Sarah has been with MCDT for five years and is servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to stock more jerrycans of local gin.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Blessing Group

texts.en:
The Blessed group is made up of five borrowers led by Mamie S., who is 33 years old and married with five children between the ages of 3 and 21 years old. The younger ones all attend school. She also cares for a sibling.

Mamie lives and sells on Johnson Street, a business district near downtown Monrovia, Liberia. Her business is in food preparation. She buys food ingredients like rice, oil, and seasonings, and she cooks and sells well-prepared food to the Johnson Street community. Mamie started this business with only Ld $500.00, but now operates with Ld $1,000.00.

Because Mamie prepares her food well and maintains a good relationship with her customers, she has many loyal customers who buy her food. Mamie hopes someday to own a restaurant and to bring success to herself and her family.

Mamie would like to obtain this loan in order to purchase more food ingredients.

loans.use: To purchase more food ingredients for her food preparation business

loans.name: Berna

texts.en:
Berna is 31 years old and married with one 15-year-old child, who attends school. Berna rents a two-room house where she lives with two other people: there is electricity but no piped water at home. Berna ensures that the family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala and she works seven days a week.

Berna owns a bar in Kawempe. She incurs extra transport costs to and from surrounding villages, so she uses bicycles whenever she can to transport her goods. The major challenges she faces in her business are seasonality and increasing prices of beer. Berna has been in this business for eight years.

She has been with MCDT for seven years, and this will be her fourteenth loan with her same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of soft drinks and beer to sell. Berna aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent home someday.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda and beer for sale

loans.name: Daylinda

texts.en:
Daylinda T. is from the village of Calaca-an. She is 49 years old. Daylinda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Daylinda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Daylinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Daylinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daylinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Daylinda is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Daylinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Remember Group

texts.en:
Taiwah T. is a widow living in the AG Quarters of Foyah District in Lofa County. She has five children whose ages range between 5 and 20 years. The younger ones attend school: the oldest school-aged child attends eighth grade.

For about three years, Taiwah has sold such items at candles, batteries, and cubes at a table at market. This business allows her to support her children and to pay their school fees. Her challenge has been the lack of finances, but she is successful in attracting her customers by providing for their needs with reasonable and affordable prices.

She dreams of a bigger business someday to adequately support her family.

loans.use: To buy additional goods such as candles, batteries, and cubes for sale

loans.name: Alicia Antonia

texts.es: Alicia Antonia T. D. M. resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán. Alicia tiene 59 años D. edad vive con su esposo quien se dedica a la agricultura y su nieto Julio D. 19 años D. edad estudiante universitario. Alicia posee su negocio D. productos para uso diario y pupuseria, ubicados en el mercado municipal D. Ahuachapán, con 20 años D. experiencia y antigüedad D. su negocio Alicia ha ganado gran cantidad D. clientes lo que le permite seguir expandiendo su negocio, es por ello que solita D. este crédito para compra D. productos que le permitan seguir creciendo en su negocio y poder aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Alicia Antonia lives is the department of Ahuachapan. Alicia is 59 years old, lives with her husband who is a farmer and with her grandson Julio (19 years old) who is a student at the university. Alicia has a store that carries products for daily use and grocery items. It is located in the municipal market of Ahuachapan. She has twenty years of experience and history in this business. Alicia has a large number of customers. This has allowed her to expand her business. It is because of this that she is asking for a loan to buy products that allow her to continue growing her business and increasing her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Mandador Group

texts.en:
Nancy T. is married and has three children whose ages range between 5 and 10 years. The older two attend school, with the elder in the seventh grade. For about two years, Nancy has been involved in the sale of dry goods such as sugar, batteries, candles, and salt. She has been challenged by family troubles as well as by financial problems, but is successful in her business and attracts her customers by good service and also by offering good and reasonable prices.

She hopes to improve her business to the point of establishing a shop. Her goal is to better support her children.

loans.use: To buy dry goods such as sugar, batteries, candles, and salt for sale

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is a 42-year-old married woman with three children aged between 10 and 24 years, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Harriet resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she lives with eight people. There is electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day.

Harriet is a tailor. She resides and works in Bwaise, a semi-urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week and serves an average of four customers a day. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.

The major challenges Harriet faces in her business are monthly seasonality and the increasing prices of sewing cloth and other fabrics.

Harriet has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for eight years. She is servicing her tenth loan working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more fabric for making clothes. Harriet aspires to seeing her business grow bigger and owning a fabric shop and a home.

loans.use: To buy more fabric for making clothes

loans.name: Marcia Lismey's Group

texts.es:
La señorita Marcia es soltera sin hijo, vive en casa de su madre   en la ciudad de Caacupé Barrio Santa Ana.
La señorita Marcia trabajaba como empleada domestica en casa familiar y poco a apoco fue ahorrando su dinero para emprender su propio negocio, aprovechando la ubicación privilegiada de su casa, que está frente de la plaza del barrio, donde concurre mucha gente a diarios.
El crédito que solicita es para compra de mercaderías como: azúcar, arroz, yerba, golosinas entre otros. 
Agradece mucho a la organización por la valiosa ayuda y espera cumplir bien para seguir trabajando con la  Fundación Paraguaya y kiva.
texts.en:
Señorita Marcia is single, has no children, and lives in her mother's house in the Santa Ana neighborhood of the City of Caacupé. Marcia worked as a domestic employee in a family home and little by little was saving her money in order to launch her own business, taking advantage of the privileged location of her house, which is in front of a main plaza where many people pass daily. The loan that she is requesting is for the purchase of merchandise such as: sugar, rice, yerba (an herb), candy and other items. She is very grateful to the organization for their valuable help, and hopes to perform well as she continues to work with the Paraguaya Foundation and Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase merchandise, drinks and food

loans.name: Jecelyn

texts.en:
Jecelyn I. is from the village of Calaca-an. She is 29 years old. Jecelyn is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Jecelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Jecelyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jecelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jecelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Jecelyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jecelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vera

texts.en: Vera is twenty – five years old. She is single with no child. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Vera is a hair dresser by profession. She works in a salon by the road side in her community. She buys her working materials such as artificial hair, pomade, weave – on, lotion, etc. from nearby towns. Vera has been in business for barely a year now and wants a loan to buy working materials on large quantities to meet her customers’ needs and satisfaction.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair

loans.name: Jehovah Shammah Group

texts.en:
Paul is 30years old he is single and father with a child who is currently in school. He is a wholesaler and trades in flour, sugar, margarine, rice etc in bags. He has his shop in the market center where he lives. He takes delivery of stock from Kumasi. He is been in business for the last three years now. He requests the loan to add to his capital so that he can buy more stock to upgrade his business. With the loan he believes it will improve his stock level to attract more customers to his shop.

He is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Jehovah Shammah’. He is the one sitting in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, grocery sellers, food vendors etc. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs like bags of rice, sugar, margarine and vegetable oil etc.

loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en: Yudaya Nanka is a 50 year married woman with eight children between 15 and 38 years of age. Two of her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. Yudaya  owns a five room house where she is staying with twelve people. There is electricity and piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi urban area  in the outskirts of Kampala  and works seven days a week.  Yudaya owns a retail shop in her home and receives at least 20 customers a day   She buys her merchandise from Kikuubo and uses public transport to and from shopping. She sells both retail and wholesale to all categories of people. Yudaya has been with MCDT for five years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her retail shop.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her retail shop

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is twenty – eight years old. She is married and has given birth to two children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Alice is a hair dresser by profession. She works in a salon by the road side in her community. Alice buys her working materials such as artificial hair, pomade, lotion, weave-ons, etc. from nearby towns. She has been in business for three years now and wants a loan to buy working materials in larger quantities to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To buy hair salon products

loans.name: Zamu

texts.en: Zamu T. is a 40 year married woman with five children between 7 and 20 years of age. All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members.  Zamu owns a four room house where she lives with three people. There is electricity and piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  Zamu has a stall selling bananas and charcoal in Kawempe Mbogo and receives at least 20 customers a day. She uses public transport to and from shopping. She sells to all categories of people and both retail and wholesale. Zamu has been with MCDT for seven years servicing her  fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her stall.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas and sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is twenty nine years old. He is married and has two children who are in school. Moses is an auto mechanic and a retailer of engine oil, brake fluid, gaskets and other car spare parts. He buys his supplies from oil filling station operators in barrels and sells in smaller quantities to his customers. Moses is handicapped by low working capital since oil prices have gone up. He therefore needs a loan to remain in business. He wants to use the loan to buy additional barrels of engine oil, gallons of brake fluid and spare parts to serve his customers. Moses believes this will enable him to make a good income from his business. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy additional barrels of engine oil, gaskets, bolts and knots, gallons of oil brake fluid and spare parts

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua is forty – five years old. She is widowed and has give birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Akua is a food vendor. She cooks and sells porridge. She sells on a table top by a road side in her community. She also sells on a local school compound. She buys bags of maize, beans and other ingredients from nearby towns. Akua has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy maize

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita S. is from the village of Balanlinao. She is 61 years old. Rosita is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Rosita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Rosita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Josphat Nyagau

texts.en:
Josphat Nyangau is a gentleman who is single. He has been running a boutique business for one year dealing in clothes and hair products. His business is situated in a slum area within East of Nairobi and it is very highly populated area. This is where his main clients are situated.

Jospaht was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he does not have a previous credit history. He has applied for a loan which he plans to use to add more stock including clothes and hair products. With the extra profits he plans to expand to selling of shoes and bags.

Jospaht describes himself as focused and hardworking and thus he believes that he will be able to achieve his hopes and dreams which are to own a wholesale boutique.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Adding stock of clothes and hair products.

loans.name: Mala-Naa I Group

texts.en:
T. S., age 22, is a married Liberian entrepreneur with two small children who are not yet in school. For about three years, he has sold dry goods such as salt and seasonings at market.

T. faces challenges with illiteracy and financial shortage, but he is successful in attracting his customers through effective customer service and courtesy. He dreams of building a provision shop which will enable him to support his children, provide for their education, and ensure that they all receive good medical treatment.

loans.use: To buy more dry goods such as salt and seasonings to sell at market

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is forty – five years old. She is married and has give birth to six children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Agnes is a food vendor. She sells kenkey and serves with pepper. She sells on a table top by a road side in her community. She also hawks to sell second hand clothes. Agnes buys bags of maize and other ingredients from nearby towns. She has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy maize

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is a 33 single mother of four children aged between 11/2 and 17 years. Two of her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. Hadjah resides and owns a four roomed house where she is staying with five people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala Q. Hadja works seven days a week.  Hadjah owns stall selling bananas in Ndeeba Market. She buys her bananas from the traders in who get them villages and doesn’t incur extra transport costs to and from shopping.  Hadjah pays monthly market dues as rent.  She sells to all categories of people and on both retail and whole sale Hadjah has been in this business for six years and with MCDT for four years servicing her fifteenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas. Hadjah is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start going to buy directly from villages.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Peter Ndegwa

texts.en:
Peter Ndegwa is 40 years old and married to one wife with three children. He lives within the Muthure area on his own farm. He is a farmer who grows vegetables, including cabbages, and supplies them to clients within the same area. This has been providing him and his family food and income to run their home. He has been running the sustenance farming business for the past two years and from this he earns a profit of about 59,600 Kenyan shillings (about $797) per month.

KADET is the first MFI he has borrowed from. He was introduced by a friend. He has applied for a loan, which he plans to use to buy more seedlings for planting.

His future hopes are to improve his farm and to have more supplies of his agricultural products.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buy more seedlings for planting

loans.name: Gift From God Group

texts.en: Teawa is illiterate and married with 3 children. She is a widow engaged in the sale of rice at retail prices, a business which she has been in for almost 10 years. Financial problems have been her biggest challenge. She is successful in her business by applying good methods in the sale of rice to consumers. She dreams of owning a shop, which will help her cater to all of her children.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice at wholesale to sell at retail

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is 24 years old she is single and seriously searching for her better half. She lives with her family a small village in the western region of Ghana. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. She is very skillful and a talented hair dresser and has been in business for three years now. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, for the reason she has four apprentices who are learning skills for the future dependency. She wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators etc. to serve her customers. She always saves parts of her savings to cater for any future eventualities.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators etc.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 37 years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. 

Grace is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice with stew. She sells from a tabletop by the roadside in her community. Grace buys bags of rice and other ingredients from nearby towns. She has been in business for more than 15 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Cesilia

texts.en:
Cesilia L., age 40, is a married with three children ages 20, 13 and 7 years.  She has a kiosk business where she sells beers, sodas and things like sugar, wheat flour, baking flour business. She started this business 10 years ago and works daily from 6am until 3pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $192. 

This will be Cesilia’s 8th loans from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to start chicken and kiosk businesses, and she has paid back her loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to buy 400 chicks.
	
Cesilia belongs to Hondogo Group

loans.use: To buy 400 chicks

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma D. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 33 years old. Alma is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Alma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Alma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
God Is Able is a group of four borrowers led by Veronica C., a 29-year-old college student and the single mother of two children aged 5 and 12 years old. Her children’s educational levels are kindergarten2 and 7th grade.

Veronica lives and works on the Old Road, a community with mixed poor and middle-class Liberians.

Veronica’s business is hairdressing and she has been running this business for more than three years. She started this business with a small shop and the rainy season was her greatest challenge. Good service and human relationships with her customers enables her to reach far in this business.

Veronica hopes to establish a bigger saloon. She needs this loan to purchase more hairdressing materials because the more materials she buys the better services she can offer.

Veronica dreams of making herself and her kids successful.

loans.use: To purchase more hairdressing materials

loans.name: Grace Nyanjau

texts.en:
Grace is separated from her husband and she has three children namely Sarah, Anne and James who are 17, 13 and 6 years old.

Grace has been in the green grocery business for one year and she operates her business in a semi slum area with a large population having clients who are residents of the area.

The client was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she has not borrowed form anywhere else before. She is acquiring the loan to buy more stock of green grocery and she also wants to venture into the business of cooking beans and other grains for sale. With the extra profits the clients intends to pay school fees.

Graces believes she is hardworking and she aims to achieve her hopes and dreams which are to own a retail shop. 


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to add stock of vegetables and potatoes.

loans.name: Georgia

texts.es:
La señora Georgia tiene 49 años, está casada con el señor Sidonio B., la pareja tiene 3 hijos.
Doña Georgia emprendió su pequeño negocio en el año 1999, vendiendo bebidas, luego fue ahorrando y con la ayuda económica D. uno sus hijos amplio su negocio, hoy día tiene una despensa, gracias a la buena atención y a la calidad D. sus productos tiene clientela formada, la Sra. Georgia comenta que sus ingresos son muy buenos y sus ventas  aumentan ya que mantiene bien surtido su despensa.
Doña Georgia agradece a fundación paraguaya y Kiva por el apoyo constante que les brinda para fortalecer su microempresa y a la vez espera recibir siempre tan valioso apoyo.
El crédito que solicita es para la compra D. yerba, azúcar, aceite, arroz, entre otros.

loans.use: Compra de yerba, azúcar, aceite y mercaderias varias.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana is 38 years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. She runs a licensed chemical store. Susana sells all kinds of drugs, both tablets and syrups alike. She sells in a store by the roadside in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns and from distributing vans. Susana has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy drugs in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy drugs in bulk

loans.name: Leokadiya

texts.en: Leokadiya isa 45 year married with six children aged between 4and 20 years Four of her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (grand son) Leokadiya resides and owns three roomed house where she is staying with six people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Kawempe Kilokole and works seven days a week. Leokadiya owns a bar selling local brew and other types of brew o and. She buys ready local brew from suppliers who get it fro m villages and the other types from delivery vans .city.  Leokadiya doesn’t pay rent for business premises.  She sells to all categories of people and on both retail and whole saleLeokadiya has been with MCDT for seven years servicing her fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to stock more brew and beers and sodas She is aspiring of oowning afully refurnished bar.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer nad soda

loans.name: Elizabeth  Wanjiru

texts.en:
Elizabeth  M. is married to Joseph Kithuka a businessman. They have three children Rahab, Margaret and Perez who are 25, 11 and 9 years old respectively.

Elizabeth has been in the green grocery business for four years and her business is in a low income area with a large population where she serves the residents of the area who are mainly casual labourers.

The client was introduced to KADET through a marketing meeting within the world vision Area Development Programme and she has no previous credit history. She has applied for a loan to add stock including irish potatoes and cereals and with the extra profit she intends to start a food kiosk. Her future hopes and dreams are to educate all her children.

Elizabeth describes herself as honest and reliable.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The client plans to add stock of irish potatoes and also start stocking cereals.

loans.name: Malaya - Together Group

texts.en: Siah is 40 years old, illiterate and a single mother of four children. She has been involved in the sale of drinks for the past three years. Her children’s ages range between 5 – 10 years. Financial difficulty has been her major challenge; but she is successful in attracting her customers by good speech. She dreams of owning a shop of her own and hopes to educate all of her children and give them good medical attention.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks

loans.name: Malaya Group

texts.en: Daniel is a secondary school dropout who is married with three children, ages 6 – 10 years along with four orphans. He has a table market business, which is the only means of making ends meet for him and his family. He is challenged with financial shortage. With his table market, he attracts his customers by the level of entertainment offered to them. He wishes to own a shop at his house and dreams of adequately educating all of his children.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods: matches, sardines, candles, etc

loans.name: Prossy Muwanguzi ‘S Group

texts.en: Prossy is a 40 year married with seven children aged between 4and 20 years All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (3 Nephews) Prossy resides and owns three roomed house where she is staying with ten people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets one meal a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Kawempe Nakamiro zone and works seven days a week.  Prossy rears pigs at her home and. She buys pigs feeds from Memgo Kisenyi where there are maize Mills and uses public transport to and from shopping.  Prossy doesn’t pay rent for business premises.  She sells to all categories of people and on both retail and whole saleProssy has been with MCDT for eleven years years servicing her twenty second loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to stock more feeds and also buy piglets.

loans.use: To buy more feeds for her pigs

loans.name: Merarda

texts.es:
La Señora Merarda está casada con el señor Cresenciano Mongelos, quién se dedica a la olería (fabricación de ladrillos), la pareja tiene 2 hijos, vive en el Barrio Jazmín de la Ciudad de Tobati unos tres kilómetros de la ciudad. 
Doña Merarda, emprendió su propia microempresa en el año 2.001, con un pequeño capital que disponía. Gracias a la buena atención y la calidad de sus productos tiene clientela formada. Doña Merarda es una persona muy sacrificada, atiende en su negocio de lunes a lunes, para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.
El crédito que solicita es para comprar mercaderías como (azúcar, yerba mate, fideos, panificados, huevo, harina, entre otros), y de esa forma ofrecer variedad a su exigente clientela.
texts.en:
Señora Merarda is married to señor Cresenciano Mongelos, who works as a brick maker. The couple has 2 children and live in the Jazmin neighborhood, about three kilometers from the city of Tobati.

Doña Merarda began her own her own micro-enterprise in 2001, with a small amount of capital she had at her disposal. Thanks to hard work and the quality of her products she has formed a customer-base.

Doña Merarda is a very self-sacrificing person. She attends to her business seven days a week in order to satisfy the needs of her customers. The loan she is applying for is to buy merchandise such as sugar, yerba mate, noodles, baked goods, eggs, and flour, among other things, and in this way offer variety to her demanding customers.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of merchandise such as sugar, yerba mate, noodles, baked goods, eggs, and flour, among other things

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
El comité “Mujeres Zeballenzes” cumple actualmente su 1º ciclo y se formó gracias al espíritu emprendedor que las mueve para cada jornada laboral, sus integrantes ya realizan una actividad productiva, por lo que ya se desenvuelven cada una en su propia microempresa. 
Utilizan su crédito para  fomentar y variar la actividad que ya están realizando como ser: compra de insumos para la fabricación de comestibles harina, carne, aceite, huevos, condimentos compra de leche azúcar, yerba, harina, sal panificados y verduras para su posterior venta, compra venta de bebidas como refrescos , gaseosas, cervezas, vinos, compra de artículos de ocasión como ropas , guantes ,bufandas, gorras etc. redoblan esfuerzos tratando de mejorar sus ingresos y así poder ofrecer a sus hijos la posibilidad de acceder a una buena preparación académica y por consiguiente una buena opción laboral.    
Compra-venta de ropas de ocasión (camperas, pulóveres, poleras, guantes, medias, remeras, jeans, gorras, bufandas etc.), compra-venta de joyas artesanales (collares, tobilleras, anillos, aros, amuletos, etc.)  compra-venta de  leche, compra-venta de azúcar, compra-venta de verduras y frutas, compra-venta de vino, aceite, arroz, fabricación y venta de comestibles artesanales como ser: butifarra, morcilla, tortillas, empanadas, croquetas, etc.

loans.use: compra de mercaderias varias como harina, carne, aceite, huevos, condimentos compra de leche azúcar, yerba, harina, sal panificados y verduras al igual que ropas y calzados.

loans.name: Irene Rose Nyambura

texts.en:
Irene N. is married to Onesmas and they have two children namely Antony and Edwin who are 15 and 5 years old respectively.

Irene has been been hawking items which include African lessos and ladies innerwear for four years.
She practices this business in areas within the low class estate where the population is large and thus a higher market.

She was introduced to KADET by existing clients. She has applied for a loan which she intends to use to add stock and venture into selling of jewellerly too. With the extra profit she plans to pay school fees, her future hopes and dreams are to own a boutique.

Irene believes that she is hardworking.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Add stock for her business

loans.name: Luz Y Progreso 3 Group

texts.en:
Inocencia is the group coordinator of her group Luz Y Progreso (Light and Progress). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian (many of whom have recently emigrated from Haiti to the DR) and Dominican clients. Her group is based in Los Alcarrizos, a dusty industrial town in north of the capital Santo Domingo, an area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. Here she makes her home with her husband and adult child in a simple structure of concrete walls and a tin roof, which she owns but does not have title to. 

Inocencia came to Esperanza with the goal of improving her business and she is excited to take her first loan. With this loan she plans to invest in acrylic nails, a nail making machine and tables to work on. With the profits from her increased business she intends to continue investing in her business and improving her quality of life. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Acrylic nails, a nail machine and tables

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie S. is from the village of Catarman. She is 58 years old and married. To make a living, Jessie owns and operates a business venture, raising cattle for sale. Jessie has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2003, Jessie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. Her aim was to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Jessie has successfully repaid her loast loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional animals. Jessie is now requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the twelfth loan taken out by Jessie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her livestock raising business

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha isa 43 year married with six children aged between 4and 20 years All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members Aisha resides and owns three roomed house where she is staying with six people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week. Aisha owns and mandazi and moves Door to Door in Kawempe. She buys baking flour and cooking oil from Kikuubo one of the busiest places in Kampala city.  Aisha doesn’t pay rent for business premises She uses public transport to and from shopping.  She sells to all categories of people and on both retail and whole saleAisha has been with MCDT for eight year servicing her twenty fourth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to stock more baking flour cooking oil and cow peas She is aspiring of employing at least 20 employees.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil nad baking flour

loans.name: Gema Group

texts.es:
ESTE GRUPO SE UBICA EN LA LOC DE TENEXTEPANGO, MUNICIPIO A., ESTADO DE MORELOS, ESTA CONFORMADO POR 4 INTEGRANTES, QUE SON LA SRA. SILVIA N. C., LA CUAL SE DEDICA AL BORDADO MANUAL DE SERVILLETAS Y MANTELES, LA SRA ARMANDA R. A. LA CUAL TIENE UNA TALACHERIA, LA SRA NANCY ADRIANA A. C. QUE TIENE UN PUESTO DE DULCES, Y LA SRA CARMELA A. V. QUE SE DEDICA A VENDER COSMETICOS POR CATALOGO, ACTUALMENTE VAN EN EL 3ER. CICLO. ESTE GRUPO SE FORMO POR RECOMENDACIONES DE UNA INTEGRANTE DE OTRO GRUPO.

EN ESTA OCASION NOS REFERIMOS EN ESPERCIAL A LA SRA. ARMANDA R. A., ACTUALMENTE CUENTA CON 34 AÑOS DE EDAD, SU FAMILIA LA CONFORMAN SU   ESPOSO, SU HIJO DE 8 AÑOS Y ESTOS MOMENTOS ESTA EMBARAZADA DE 4 MESES, LA SRA ARMANDA HA FORMADO PARTE DE ESTE GRUPO DESDE EL 1ER CICLO, ACTUALMENTE CUENTA CON UN CREDITO DE $5000,EL CUAL INVIRTIO EN VALVULAS, PARCHES Y CALIBRADORES, YA QUE SU NEGOCIO ES UNA TALACHERIA "DIAZ", EN EL CUAL BRINDA EL SERVICIO DE PARCHES, VENTA DE LLANTAS USADAS Y NUEVAS.

ELLA INICIO CON SU NEGOCIO DE TALACHERIA HACE DOS AÑOS Y MEDIO, DEBIDO A QUE TRABAJABA EN UNA LLANTERA GRANDE EN LA CD. DE CUAUTLA, SUS JEFES LE OFRECIERON RENTAR UN LOCAL EN LA CENTRAL DE ABASTOS DE LA CD DE CUAUTLA, PARA QUE PUSIERA SU NEGOCIO PROPIO, AL COMENTARLE A SU ESPOSO QUE EN ESE TIEMPO ERA EMPLEADO, ESTUBO DE ACUERDO EN ABRIR EL LOCAL Y ASI LO HICIERON, PASADO UN TIEMPO, CON LAS GANANCIAS DEL 1ER NEGOCIO PUSIERON OTRO Y CON APOYO DEL GOBIERNO COMPRAROR UNA DESMONTADORA Y BALANCEADORA. SU 2DO NECIO ESTA, UBICADO EN TENEXTEPANGO, EL CUAL ES ATENDIDO POR EL CUÑADO DE LA SRA ARMANDA, LA COMPETENCIA QUE TIENEN SON 2 TALACHERIAS MAS, SIN EMBARGO MENCIONA ORGULLOSA QUE LOS CLIENTE PREFIEREN EL SERVICIO DE SU NEGOCIO YA QUE LOS CARACTERIZA LA RAPIDEZ Y EFICENCIA, DEBIDO A QUE ELLOS UTILIZAN MAQUINARIA, LO CUAL EN OTROS NEGOCIOS HACEN MANUAL Y ESTO LES LLEVA MAS TIEMPO.

LOS PLANES QUE TIENE ES SEGUIR INVIRTIENDO EN SUS NEGOCIOS, PARA OBTENER UTILIDADES QUE INVERTIRA EN SU VIVIERNDA (PISO, HERRERIA Y REPILLADO) YA QUE LA QUE LA MOTIVA A ECHARLE GANAS ES DARLES UNA MEJOR VIVIENDA ASUS HIJOS.

Y A LARGO PLAZO DESEARIA DAR EL SERVICIO DE ALINEACION SIN EMBARGO PARA PODER DAR ESE SERVICIO SE REQUIERE DE UN CAPITAL $100,000 APROXIMADAMENTE, QUE EN ESTOS MOMENTOS CREE NO ESTAR APTA PARA PODER PAGAR, YA QUE NO QUIERE SOBREENDEUDARSE CON UN CAPITAL TAN GRANDE, ES POR ESO QUE QUIERE SEGUIR TRABAJANDO COMO HASTA AHORA CON LOS CREDITOS DE FUNDACION REALIDAD, Y DA LAS GRACIAS POR LA CONFIANZA QUE SE LES HA BRINDADO AL PRESTARLES LOS CREDITOS , POR QUE DICE QUE SI LE HA SERVIDO
DE MUCHO.
texts.en:
This group is located in Tenextepango, A. municipality, state of Morelos. It’s made of 4 members who are Mrs. Silvia N. C., whose works making hand-embroidered napkins and tablecloths, Mrs. Armanda R. A., who has a mechanic shop, and Mrs. Carmela A. V., who works selling cosmetics by catalog. Currently, they are in their third cycle. This group was formed on the recommendation from a member of another group. At this time, we would like to call your attention to Mrs. Armanda R. A.. She is now 34 years old. Her family consists of her husband, her 8-year-old son, and she is presently 4 months pregnant. Mrs. Armanda has been part of this group since the first cycle. Currently, she has a loan of $5000, which she invested in valves, patches and calibrators, since her business is a mechanic shop, “Diaz,” that offers service in patching and sales of new and used tires. She began her mechanic shop two and a half years ago, because she was working in a large tire shop in the city of Cuautla. Her bosses offered her a shop rental in the center of the market of Cuautla, so that she could establish her own business. When she told her husband, who was employed at the time, he agreed to open the shop, and they did. After some time, with the earnings from their first shop, they established another and, with government support, bought a tire press and balancer. Their second business was born, located in Tenextepango and tended by the brother-in-law of Mrs. Armanda, who has experience in two other mechanic shops. However, he says with pride that the customers prefer the service at this shop for its speed and efficiency, due to the fact that they use machines to do what other businesses do by hand, which takes more time. Her plans are to continue investing in their businesses, to get the investment for utilities needed for their home (floor, ironwork and exterior walls). The motivation that drives them is the desire to give their children a good home. In the long-term, they want to offer alignment, however to give this service would require approximately $100,000 in capital. At this moment, they do not want to grossly indebt themselves with a loan this large. So they keep working until this loan is more realistic and give thanks for the trust that they have been offered through these loans. They say that they have served them well.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase valves, patches and calibrators

loans.name: Stephen Kungu

texts.en: Stephen N. is married with no children yet. His business is vending water which he has done for eight years now. His area of business is in Ruai Centre which is a rural setting. He supply's water to hotels and homes with dairy animals and also to individuals for domestic use. Stephen was introduced to KADET through marketing from one of the KADET offices. He has applied for a loan which he plans to use to buy a water tank for water storage. With the extra profit from his business, he intends to buy a dairy cow to diversify his business opportunities. He aspires to keeping several dairy cows in future. Stephen describes himself as focused and hardworking. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a water tank for water storage

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is thirty – eight years old. She is married and has give birth to six children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Dorcas is a trader. She trades in provision and other food items. She sells in a store by the road side in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Dorcas has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provision

loans.name: One World I Group

texts.en:
Finda is a 28-year-old illiterate single mother of two children, aged 2 and 5 years. She’s currently supporting her two children along with one orphan.

Finda is a widow and is involved in bread-making, a business which she has been in for the past two years. Her challenges have been seriously with the lack of financing. She’s successful in attracting her customers by means of good speech and the use of adequate recipes required for bread-making.

Finda dreams of improving her business to sustain her three children and also to educate them properly.

loans.use: To buy flour, oil, baking powder, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema is a 27 years married with three children aged between 1and 6 years Two of her children go to school.  She takes care of additional family members.  Rehema resides and rents a two roomed house where she is staying with five people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works six days a week. Rehema sells second hand clothes in a shop in kanyanya and buys these s clothes from Owino Market one of the busiest markets in Kampala city   She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping The major challenges she faces in her business are seasonality and increasing prices of second ,high transport costs and defaulters . Rehema has been in this business for two years.  She has been with MCDT for five year servicing her tenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Rehema is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start importing these clothes directly from UK and USA.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Djénèba

texts.fr:
Madame Djénèba D.  a  49 ans, mariée et mère de quatre enfants dont 2 garçons et 2 filles. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants au quartier Noumouso de la ville de Kadiolo (dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Djénèba D.  fait ce commerce d’articles divers depuis maintenant 4 ans, en plus de ses obligations professionnelle, car elle est enseignante à l’école du quartier Noumousso. 
Elle est beaucoup sollicitée en cette période (approche de l’ouverture des classes et de la fête de ramadan) par sa clientèle en nette croissance.  
Afin de satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle sollicite son second prêt individuel auprès de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, le premier s’étant  bien déroulé. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 7 pièces de pagnes bazins  et 4 paquets de fournitures  scolaires. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville chez les grossistes et  revend  dans la ville de Kadiolo et à l’école  où elle enseigne en détail, au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage  réaliser avec ce prêt, un bénéfice mensuel de 15.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Djénèba D. is 49 years old and the mother of 4 children - 2 boys and 2 girls. She lives with her spouse and their children in the Noumouso neighborhood of the city of Kadiolo (in the 3rd administrative region in the Republic of Mali).

Mrs. Djénèba D. has done this business for 4 years now, selling a variety of items. In addition to her professional obligations, she also teaches at the school in the neighborhood of Noumousso.

She is highly requested by her clientele during this period (with the approach of the opening of classes and the holiday of Ramadan). As such, she can satisfy this clientele more by growing and she is requesting a second individual loan from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, having fully repaid her first loan.

With this loan she intends to purchase 2 pieces of "pagnes bazins" (colorful wax cloths) and 4 packets of school supplies. She supplies herself from wholesalers in the market of the city of Sikasso and re-sells in the city of Kadiolo and in to the school, where she sells at retail prices for cash, or credit to a clientele consisting of men and women. With this loan she envisions earning an income of 15,000 FCFA, which she will use to increase her business' funds, contribute to family expenditures and pay the interest for her loan.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothes and school supplies for resale

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina, 37 years old, is divorced and has one child who is in school. She and her child live in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso, a commercial and farming town in the western region of Ghana.

Faustina is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice balls. She sells her wares at a roadside table in her community. She purchases bags of rice and other ingredients from vendors in nearby towns. Faustina has been in business for over three years. She hopes to obtain a loan to buy goods in bulk in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Sarah Kabenge's Group

texts.en:
Sarah, age 25, is a tailor. She also works as a teacher at a tailoring and knitting school in Makerere Kikoni. She is unmarried and has no children, although she does take care of additional family members. Sarah rents a one-room house which she shares with three people. There is electricity in the home, but no piped water. Sarah ensures that they get three meals a day.

Sarah resides and works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala, and she works six days a week. She buys threads and other materials from Kikuubo, one of the busiest marketplaces in the city of Kampala. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping at the market, which is one of the biggest markets in Uganda, so she often uses public transport. The major challenges she faces in her business are seasonality, increasing prices of thread, and high transport costs. Sarah has been in this business for three years.

She has been with MCDT for one year and she and her group mate are now requesting thier third loan together. She wants to use this loan to buy thread, needles, knitting materials, and dressmaking materials. Sarah aspires to see her tailoring business grow bigger and dreams of eventually owning her own sweater-knitting school.

loans.use: To buy thread, needles, knitting materials, and dressmaking materials

loans.name: Maria Inés

texts.es:
María Inés tiene 45 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a su padre en el distrito de La Victoria, ubicado a cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella se dedica al diseño y confección de toda clase de artículos de peluche, maneja el negocio desde hace más de seis años y confecciona sus productos de acuerdo a la temporada del año para luego ofrecerlos en las diferentes urbanizaciones de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Usualmente confecciona muñecos, fundas para muebles e incluso se dedica a la costura, pero actualmente está confeccionando nuevos productos para cubrir la demanda propia de la temporada navideña. Es por ello que está solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de una remalladora industrial que le permita facilitar su trabajo y aumentar su producción así como de más material para seguir confeccionando sus muñecos.

Con este ingreso ella sustenta la economía de su hogar ya que su padre no puede trabajar debido a su avanzada edad. Maria Inés sueña con extender su taller y obtener un local propio en el centro de la ciudad de Chiclayo en donde pueda ofrecer sus productos con mayor comodidad. Ella es muy conocida por la calidad y responsablidad con la que confecciona sus productos.
texts.en:
Maria Ines is 45 years old, is single and lives with her father in the district of La Victoria, located five minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She designs and sews all types of stuffed animals. She has been doing this for more than six years. She makes different products depending on the seasons of the year and she offers her products in different parts of the city. She usually makes dolls, furniture covers and she also makes clothes. She actually is making new products to meet the demand for Christmas items. It is because of this that she is asking “Edpyme Alternativa” for a loan of 1500 new soles. She hopes to use the money to buy a chain stitch sewing machine, which will make her work easier and increase her production. With this machine she will be able to continue making her dolls. With this loan she will support her home and her father, who is not able to work due to his advanced age. Maria Ines dreams of growing her workshop and obtaining her own location in the center of the city of Chiclayo, where she would be able to more easily offer her products.
