Cledy is a member of the Communal Bank called Ccori Ayllu, which means Family of Gold. Cledy is 19, married, and has one child. Cledy makes typical breads in her parents’ oven. She does this with help from her husband. She makes her sales in different towns in the region. Cledy needs a loan for 1,000 PEN to buy flour. Cledy’s dreams are to have a bakery in the center of the city and to improve her finances.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy flour

loans.name: Adela

texts.es:
Adela es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro.
Adela es casada, tiene 31 años y 2 hijos, Adela tiene un puesto en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad en donde vende papa, producto que adquiere de los productores, actividad que realiza todos los días desde la madrugada.
Adela necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de papa.
Los sueños de Adela son seguir adelante, llevar sus productos a la capital.

loans.use: Para la compra de papa.

loans.name: Alicia Adelayda

texts.es:
Alicia es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro.
Alicia es casada, tiene 31 años y 4 hijos, Alicia tiene una polleria en un local alquilado ubicado en una avenida céntrica, actividad que viene realizando hace 3 meses y le esta yendo bien. Alicia tiene proyectado implementar una tienda de abarrotes.
Alicia necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz y azúcar.
Los sueños de Alicia son que sus hijos sean profesionales y tengan un negocio propio.
texts.en:
Alicia is a member of the Communal Bank called Ccori Ayllu, which means Family of Gold. Alicia is 31, married, and has four children. Alicia has a business selling cooked chicken in a rented space, which is located on a central avenue. She has been doing this for three months, and it is going well for her. Alicia plans to set up a grocery store. Alicia needs a loan for 900 PEN to buy rice and sugar. Alicia’s dreams are that her children become professionals and that they have their own business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Lud Edith

texts.es:
Lud es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro.
Lud es conviviente, tiene 22 años y esta esperando a su primer hijo, estudiante de cosmetología y contabilidad, Lud vende ropa a pedido, que ofrece a amigos, familiares, sus ventas son al crédito, además Lud viaja a las ferias en donde también vende ropa.
Lud necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa.
Los sueños de Lud son terminar de estudiar su carrera.
texts.en:
Lud is a member of the Communal Bank called Ccori Ayllu, which means Family of Gold. Lud is 22, in a common law marriage, and expecting her first child. She is an accounting and cosmetology student. Luz sells clothes by order to her friends and family. Her sales are on credit. Lud also travels to the fairs where she sells clothes. Lud needs a loan for 900 PEN to buy clothes. Lud’s dream is to finish studying for her career.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes

loans.name: Rubi Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer, Collpani, se reunen cada dos semanas la Asociación Comunal Rubi y estan en el ciclo 8, liderizadas por su presidenta Isabel I., elaboran su reglamento interno.
Ellas tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de comida, carne, libros, yutes, cosméticos y tienda de barrio. Necesitan el préstamo para comprar insumos y mercadería que les  permita generar mayores ingresos y poder cubrir las necesidades básicas de sus familias. Es el caso de Wendy C. de 24 años,  vende carne en diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto, y requiere comprar mercadería.
texts.en:
The Rubi Communal Bank meets in one of the Pro Mujer community centers, Collpani, every two weeks. They are in their eighth cycle. Led by their president, Isabel I., they make their own rules. They have their own businesses like selling food, meat, books, jute, and cosmetics. Some also have grocery stores. They need a loan to buy supplies and merchandise, which will allow them to generate greater income and be able to cover their families’ basic needs. That is the case for Wendy C. who is 24. She sells meat at different fairs in the city of El Alto. She needs to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies and merchandise

loans.name: Maritza Felicita

texts.es: Maritza Felicita M. tiene la edad de 56 años, su estado civil es casada. Doña Maritza tiene 2 hijos que trabajan por cuenta propia. La actividad económica de Maritza es la venta de repuestos de automotrices. Doña Maritza es una mujer muy luchadora y emprendedora, por lo que disfruta mucho de su negocio. Hace más de 16 años que  se dedica a este negocio. Doña Maritza dio inicio su pequeño negocio por el deseo de superación ya que tenía que mantener a sus hijos. Además ella realizaba la compra de una manera mucho más favorable para después ella realizar su venta, la mayoría de sus clientes son los carreteros.  El financiamiento es destinado para capital de trabajo y el dinero será utilizado para la compra de llantas, válvulas de aire, mangueras, retenedores entre otros. El deseo de Maritza es de proporcionarles a sus hijos la educación necesaria para que sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
Maritza Felicita M. is 56 years old and married. She has two children who work on their own. Maritza sells automotive parts. Maritza is an enterprising and tenacious woman so she enjoys her job very much. She has been working in this business for 16 years. Maritza started her own small business with a desire to improve her standard of living since she needed to raise her children. Through intelligent economical choices in her initial purchases, Maritza was able to capitalize on her profits upon the resale of her products. The majority of her clients are drivers. The money will be used for capital to purchase items such as tires, air valves, hoses, retainers among others. Maritza’s wish is to provide her children with the necessary education so they may one day be competent professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: business capital

loans.name: Lipcia Carolina

texts.es: Lipcia Carolina Munguía es cliente de Fundación León 2000, es una madre soltera. Tiene 1 hijo a su cargo que todavía depende de ella. El espíritu emprendedor y trabajador de Lipcia es lo mejor para ella, pues fue por medio de esas fuerzas que la motivo para  establecer la actividad económica como es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio, su negocio está ubicado en un sector donde transitan muchos clientes, por lo que ofrece sus productos de una manera muy entusiasmada y esto es lo que más le atrae a sus clientes. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de  ropa, calzado, cosméticos, ropa interior. Por lo que el sueño de Lipcia es brindarle a su familia las condiciones adecuadas de vida.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.es:
María Concepción Holguín Cedeño es  socia del Banco Comunal Dinámicas  ubicado en el cantón  Tosagua a una hora de Portoviejo  en la Provincia de Manabí. 

 María Concepción es una mujer  dedicada a la costura,  profesión que desarrolla  desde que era soltera, ella  junto a su esposo  viven de  esta profesión desde hace muchos años, en los actuales momentos el esposo esta delicado de salud y es ella  quien continua con esta labor, cose ropa para damas y camisas  para caballeros. 

La sastrería la tiene en su  casita propia ubicada en el centro de la ciudad de Tosagua, y es María Concepción la que tiene que solventar los gastos del hogar con el apoyo de sus hijos  que actualmente adquirieron un disco móvil para ayudarse económicamente debido que ahora la gente prefiere comprar ropa ya confeccionada en boutique y eso a hecho disminuir  un poco el negocio.

El préstamo que la señora María  Concepción esta solicitando será para invertir en sus dos negocios, uno en materiales de costura como tela, hilos, cierres, botones, etc.  y lo demás para comprar una pantalla gigante para su disco móvil  y un ecualizador.
texts.en:
María Concepción Holguín Cedeño is a member of the "Dinámicas" Community Bank located in the territory of Tosagua one hour from Portoviejo in the province of Manabí. María Concepción is a woman who is dedicated to sewing, a profession that she developed since when she was single. She and her husband have lived off this profession for many years. Currently, her husband is in delicate health and it is she who continues with this work. She sews clothing for women and shirts for men. The tailor shop that she has in her own little home is located in the center of the city of Tosagua and it is María Concepción who has to pay the bills with the support of her children who recently acquired a mobile disco to help them economically since right now people prefer to buy pre-made clothing from a boutique and this has caused business to slow down. The loan that María Concepción is requesting will be invested in her two businesses: one in sewing materials such as fabric, thread, closures, buttons, etc. and the rest to buy a gigantic screen for her mobile disco and an equalizer.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sewing materials such as fabric, thread, closures, buttons, etc. and the rest to buy a gigantic screen for her mobile disco and an equalizer.

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es:
La señora María Teresa C. Solís es socia del banco Comunal Dapreydi en Tosagua en la provincia de Manabí, ella está casada y sus hijos ya son mayores e independientes

María Teresa es  comerciante desde hace 7 años,  tienen su negocio de artículos de primera necesidad ubicado en el mercado de la localidad donde atienden solo los sábados,   junto a su esposo  comparten las actividades ya que él tiene un negocio de venta de platos en el mismo mercado.

Además tienen una pequeña tienda en su casa donde atiende de domingo a viernes, su esposo se encarga de comprar los productos a los mayoristas y distribuir en los dos locales.

Con  el préstamo que ha solicitado a la fundación lo va a invertir en la compra productos  de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, aceite, sal, fideos, etc. Para abastecer mejor sus tiendas de abastos.

El sueño de  María Teresa es poner un local de venta de ropa para toda la familia así como sabanas y edredones, pero sin dejar su tienda que es su sustento diario.
texts.en:
María Teresa C. Solís is a member of the Dapreydi Community Bank in Tosagua in the province of Manabí. She is married and her children are older and independent. María Teresa has been a merchant since she was seven years old. She has a business selling basic necessities located in the local market which she attends only on Saturdays. Alongside her husband, they share the work since he has a business selling dishes in the same market. Additionally, they have a small shop in their home which they attend to Sunday through Thursday. Her husband is in charge of buying products at wholesale and distributing them to the two locations. With the loan that she has requested from the foundation, she is going to invest in the purcahse of basic necessity products such as rice, sugar, oil, salt, noodles, etc. in order to stock her shops better. María Teresa's dream is to start a shop selling clothing for the whole family as well as sheets and duvets but without neglecting their shop which is their daily bread.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products such as rice, sugar oil, salt, noodles to stock their shops.

loans.name: El Ceibo Group

texts.es:
Blanca M. N. de 49 años de edad, ubicada en la parte izquierda de la foto, es la coordinadora del grupo El ceibo. A pesar de que ella no sabe ni leer ni escribir, desde sus 17 años se dedica a la compra de cultivos o cosechas, que luego distribuye a los mercaderes de Masaya.

Apoyada de sus 4 hijos menores, se dedican a este negocio, que inició con capital propio y a menor escala y que gracias a los créditos de ADIM a logrado engrandecer y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.

Este crédito lo invertirá en la cosecha de yuca, quequisque, limones y naranjas. Su mayor anhelo es que sus hijos alcancen lo que ella no pudo, que fue una educación. “Si yo he logrado mucho, aun no sabiendo leer ni escribir; cuanto pueden lograr mis hijos aprendiendo mas” nos dice Blanca.

Ana L.  posee un negocio de floristería, compra flores naturales en viveros y también artificiales y  hacer arreglos florales decorativos; Marina Gonzales trabaja en la compra venta de verduras.
texts.en:
Blanca M. N. (the woman pictured on the left) is 49 years old and the coordinator for the group “El Ceibo”. Even though she cannot read or write, she has been engaged in the business of buying crops and selling them at the markets in Masaya for the past 17 years.

She has the support of her 4 dependent children. Blanca started her business on a smaller scale using her own capital. Thanks to the loans available from ADIM, she was able to expand her business and improve her quality of life.

Blanca will use her loan to buy cassava, taro root, lemons, and oranges. Her greatest wish is for her children to receive the education she was not able to attain. “If I am able to accomplish much without knowing how to read or write, imagine what my children can achieve if they are able to learn,” says Blanca.

Ana L. manages a florist. She buys natural flowers from nurseries as well as artificial ones for making decorative arrangements. Marina Gonzales works as a vegetable vendor.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seasonal produce

loans.name: Gloria Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Gloria Margarita Vélez es otra socia activa del Banco Comunal Dinámicas   ubicado en el cantón  Tosagua a una hora de Portoviejo  en la Provincia de Manabí. Gloria es casada,  tiene 66 años pero es una persona muy jovial, argumenta que aun le quedan fuerzas para salir adelante, su esposo era agricultor pero por problemas de salud ya no trabaja  y es ella la que solventa los gastos de su hogar.

Gloria  tiene un pequeño bazar de materiales de costura ya lleva tres años en esta actividad,  en su  casa tiene unas vitrinas donde ofrece a sus clientes desde agujas hasta los más  bellos botones para acabos de sus prendas  y adornos para el hogar.

El préstamo que Gloria está solicitando a la  fundación es para invertir en la compra de  materiales para el bazar como relojes, porta retratos y álbumes para fotos, así como también mas artículos de costura para sus clientes dedicados a la confección de ropa.

El sueño de Gloria es terminar de construir su casa porque aun le falta la cocina y el comedor.
texts.en:
Gloria Margarita Vélez is an active member of the Dinámicas Communal Bank, which is located in Tosagua County an hour from Portoviejo in the Manabí Province. Gloria is 66 and married. She is a very jovial person who says that she still has the strength to get ahead. Her husband is a farmer. Due to health problems, he no longer works. She is the one that pays the household expenses. Gloria has a small bazaar where she sells sewing and dressmaking materials. She has been doing this for three years. In her house she has display cases where she offers her customers things like needles, the most beautiful buttons for finishing clothes, and decorations for the home. The loan that Gloria is asking the foundation for is to buy materials like clocks, picture frames, photo albums, and sewing supplies for her customers who make clothes. Gloria’s dream is to finish building her house because it still needs a kitchen and a dining room.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for her bazar like clocks, picture frames, photo albums, and sewing supplies

loans.name: Bella Vista Group

texts.es:
Perla Cristina G. de 27 años de edad es una mujer proactiva y de mucho carácter; coordinadora del grupo Bella Vista y la que promueve y organiza al grupo de manera tal que su record crediticio se mantenga limpio.

Perla tiene familiares en Rivas, en una zona bastante árida, ella compra frutas y verduras en Masaya, ya que esta ciudad es muy característica por la agricultura y lo lleva a Rivas donde su hermana le ayuda a venderlo. 

Su crédito lo quiere para la compra de productos de temporada, con su capital propio pretende mantener la compra venta de verduras, pero con el crédito invertir en la compra de otros productos que se puedan llevar a esas zonas. Como juguetes, ropa, calzado, entre otros. 

Su único apoyo es su hermana, y su razón de esforzarse es su pequeña de 4 años. Por ella sigue adelante aunque siendo soltera es más difícil.

Escarleth posee un tramo en el mercado mayoreo de Managua donde vende productos perecederos; y José Vicente es conduce un taxi propio y sus créditos los usa para el mantenimiento del vehículo.
texts.en:
Perla Cristina G., age 27, is a proactive woman of great character. She is the coordinator of the Bella Vista group and promotes and organizes the group in a way which maintains a clean credit record. Perla has relatives in Rivas, a rather dry area. She buys fruits and vegetables in Masaya, since this city is well-known for agriculture, and takes it to Rivas where her sister helps her sell them. She wants the loan for the purchase of seasonal produce. With her own funds she will try to continue the purchase and sale of vegetables, but she will invest the loan in the purchase of other products that they can take to the zone around Rivas. These include toys, clothing, and footwear, among other things. Her only support is from her sister, and her reason for exerting herself is her 4 year old little girl. That is why she forges ahead, although being single is more difficult. Escarleth has a place in the Managua wholesale market where she sells perishable produce, and José Vicente drives his own taxi. They will use their loans for the maintenance of the vehicle.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seasonal produce

loans.name: Rosa Elena

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Elena Macías P.  es socia del Banco Comunal Dapreydi, ubicado en Tosagua, Provincia de Manabí, ella es profesora y dueña de una escuelita de la localidad en la que atiende junto a su esposo, llevan en esta actividad desde hace 20 años, en la mañana dan clases en su institución y por la tarde en un colegio fiscal donde laboran como maestros.

Doña Rosa tiene 140 estudiantes en su escuela, trabajan con 10 docentes, la labor de esta socia empieza desde muy temprano y termina a las 6:30 de la tarde y el  fin de semana se dedica a descansar y a preparar  material de trabajo para la siguiente semana, es una tarea que necesita de mucha dedicación y esfuerzo pero no le importa porque ama lo que hace.

Rosita nos comenta que hace un tiempo atrás  tenían un negocio de venta de fritada y hamburguesas  les iba muy bien pero el tiempo no les alcanzaba para desarrollar las dos actividades por lo que decidieron  cerrar el negocio de comida rápida.

El préstamo que Rosita está solicitando a la Fundación  lo va a invertir en el mejoramiento de la escuela, pintar las aulas, arreglar las bancas,  así como también en la compra de productos para implementar el bar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rosa Elena is a member of the “Dapreydi” Community Bank located in Tosagua, in the Manabi Province. She is a teacher and the owner of a local little school in her town. She shares ownership with her husband. They have been working at this activity for more than twenty years. In the morning they teach classes at this institution and in the afternoon they teach classes at a public high school where they work as teachers. Mrs. Rosa has 140 students at her school. They work with ten teachers who work from early in the morning until 6:30 in the evening. On the weekends they rest and prepare lessons for the next week. This work requires much dedication and effort but that isn’t important because they love what they do. Rosita told us that in the past they had a business that sold frittatas and hamburgers. It went well but they didn’t have enough time to develop two businesses so they decided to close the food business. The loan that Rosita is asking for from the Foundation will be invested in school improvement. She will paint the classrooms, fix the benches and also she will buy products for the snack bar.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To improve her school, paint the classrooms, fix the benches, and buy products for the snack bar.

loans.name: Fatima Beatriz Blanca

texts.es:
La señora  Fátima Beatriz Blanca S. Z. es socia del Banco Comunal  Dapreydi  en el cantón Tosagua en la provincia de Manabí  desde hace un ciclo.

Fátima  es  madre soltera tiene una hija de 30 años que  vive en España desde hace seis años y a partir de entonces vive sola en Tosagua.  Ella  se dedica al comercio hace 20 años  y lo realiza  desde su  casa, vende  bebidas gaseosas, cervezas, algo de ropa para niños y productos de belleza Yambal que los adquiere a los mayoristas en Portoviejo a una hora de su lugar de residencia. 

Cuenta doña Fátima que sus clientes la visitan  en su casa por lo que  no se ha visto en la necesidad de salir a la calle a vender sus productos y no ha descuidado su negocio de bebidas gaseosas obteniendo bastantes clientes desde su domicilio.

Con el préstamo solicitado a  la Fundación Espoir  va a invertir en su negocio  comprando bebidas gaseosas surtidas, ropa y productos Yambal para su exigente clientela, y espera a corto plazo montar  un bazar, comprar vitrinas y ropa para damas caballeros y niños como  pantalones, blusas, y camisas, zapatos y artículos para el hogar.
texts.en:
Fátima Beatriz Blanca S. Z. is a member of the Dapreydi Communal Bank in Tosagua County in the Manabí Province. She has been a member for one cycle. Fátima is a single mother. Her 30 year old daughter has lived in Spain for six years. Since then Fátima has lived alone in Tosagua. For 20 years she has been selling soft drinks, beer, some children’s clothing, and Yambal beauty products from her house. She gets them from the wholesalers in Portoviejo, which is one hour from where she lives. Fátima says that her customers come to her house, so she does not see the need to leave and sell her products on the street. She has not neglected her business of selling soft drinks. She has plenty of customers from her home. With the loan she is asking Fundación Espoir for she will invest in her business and buy soft drinks to keep in stock, clothes, and Yambal products for her discerning customers. She plans to soon start a bazaar, buy display cases, and buy clothes for women, men, and children. She will buy pants, blouses, shirts, shoes, and articles for the home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks, clothes, and Yambal beauty products to better stock her business

loans.name: María Auxiliadora

texts.es:
La señora María Auxiliadora R. G. es socia del Banco Comunal Dapreydi en Tosagua un cantón de la provincia de Manabí,  está casada desde hace 16 años tiene dos hijos de 15 y 30 años.

 María Auxiliadora se dedica a la preparación de alimentos,  tiene un restaurant en el centro de la ciudad donde  ofrece desayunos, almuerzos, y platos típicos de la región como caldo de gallina criolla, viche, seco de gallina, además es  ella la que se encarga de la sazón y cuenta con la ayuda de una señora.

María Auxiliadora  viene realizando esta labor desde hace muchos años, atiende de lunes a sábado de 6:30 a 15:00, el tiempo que le queda de la tarde lo dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar y a  dejar  adelantando su trabajo para el día siguiente, cuenta que durante estos años ha logrado mantener clientes fijos que llegan ya  a cuarenta.

El préstamo que está solicitando es para invertir  en su negocio en la compra de víveres para preparar sus comidas y para adquirir menaje de cocina para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes. 

El sueño de María Auxiliadora es tener un local bastante amplio para su restaurant y que sea de su propiedad,  así como incursionar en la venta de ropa y cosméticos  ya que es un negocio muy rentable.
texts.en:
María Auxiliadora R. G. is a member of Dapreydi community bank in Tosagua, part of Manabí province. She has been married for 16 years and has two children, ages 15 and 30. María Auxiliadora prepares food; she has a restaurant in the city center where she offers breakfast, lunch, and typical regional dishes such as caldo de gallina criolla (traditional chicken broth), viche (thick fish soup with plantain), and seco de gallina (chicken stew cooked in a sauce of beer, onions, garlic, peppers, tomatoes, herbs and spices). She also manages the restaurant and employees an assistant. She has done this work for many years. Her restaurant is open Monday through Saturday from 6:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. During the rest of the afternoon she does housework and prepares for the following day's work. Over the years she has gained many loyal customers. The loan she is requesting will be invested in her business for the purchase of food supplies and kitchenware, so that she can offer the best service to her customers. María Auxiliadora's dream is to own a space that is big enough to have her restaurant in as well as to venture into clothing and cosmetics sales, which are both very profitable businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food supplies and kitchenware.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim B., 37, is married with three young children and resides in Kompong Cham Province with husband. To make a living, she is engaged in the agriculture sector of growing potatoes on her plot of farmland, earning approximately an income of US $2 per day. Her husband operates his car as a taxi driver from province to province, earning an income of US $6 per day which is the primary source of income for the family. These businesses have significant on the improvements of B.’s standard of living; therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase few kinds of vegetable from local farmers to sell at the market to make profit.

loans.use: buy vegetable and fruit

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao P., 41, is married with three children and resides in Kompong Cham Province. The source of income is generated primarily from her husband whose business is purchasing cows from the local farmers in his villages and other nearby places in the province to resell in the town. He is able to earn an income of US $ 10 per day. The family is also assisted by one of the children who is currently employed in a local garment factory with a reasonable income to earn the living and to support the family. P.’s standard of living has been improved since her husband starts this business; therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more cows for her husband to expand and improve his business.

loans.use: buy cows

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Yen V., 38, is married with two children and resides in the Kompong Cham Province. To make a living, her husband (pictured) has to travel from place to place to find work as a construction worker. He is able to earn a daily income of $4, which is the primary source of income for the family. The family is also assisted by the two children, who are currently working as their father does with a reasonable income to earn a good living.

V. really wants to take a loan of $500 to purchase fertilizer for her rice fields. She hopes she will be able to make her rice fields efficient enough to produce maximum outputs.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma N. is engaged in the vending of vegetables and fruit in their village at Rizaluna, Cordon, Isabela. She stands as both father and mother to her two children: Angel Queen, three years old; and John Angel, two years old. Gemma is thankful because, despite all the problems she encounters in life, she remains strong in overcoming all of those things through the guidance of our Almighty God.

Gemma would like to improve her business so that she will be able to increase the income she generates but, sad to say, her business capital is not enough. Thus, to further improve her business, she decided to seek the assistance of Kiva lenders. She is asking for a loan that will help her develop and progress her vending. She is requesting PHP 5,000 to use in her business buying and selling different vegetables and fruit.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana E. is a chicken raiser in their peaceful village of Rizaluna Cordon, Isabela. She is already 49 years old, she is married to Danny E. Sr. who is a house carpenter. They have been blessed with five children, one of them are already married and have their own family now. Her four children are still single and some of them are still studying. They are as follows: Joy-25 years old; Rica-22 years old; Danny Jr.-19 years old they are all high school graduate and the youngest is Debby-14 years old who is now a second year high school student. Juliana hopes that she could continue to support the schooling of her youngest daughter by making her business productive. 

		Juliana said that raising chicken is quite hard especially when she doesn’t have enough capital to buy for their needed feeds. Though it’s hard, Juliana still continue raising her chicken because it is beneficial to them particularly the profit they get from it. Juliana would like to develop her business but her capital is insufficient that is why she is requesting a loan amounting to PHP4, 000 for her business improvement.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Vending of native cakes is what Erlinda E. does during her business day. She starts vending her homemade cooked native cakes at 9:00 a.m. and stops selling when they are all sold. She then repeats her business routine again the following day, and so forth.

Because she wants her business to grow and increase her daily income, Erlinda is hoping to borrow PHP 4,000 from Kiva lenders as additional business capital. She hopes that lenders will provide her with the loan that she has requested, for it will allow her to develop her vending business.

Erlinda is married to Eduardo and the couple is blessed with five children: the eldest is already married; Elpidio - 21 years old is a high school graduate; Jennelyn - 19 years old; Edralyn - 11 years old, is a grade-II pupil; and Angelica - 6 years old, is a grade-I pupil.

Erlinda hopes that she will be able to sustain the needs of her family, most especially the financial needs of her children in their pursuit of a good education.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora A. is from the village of San Juan Quezon, Isabela. She manages selling generic medicines in their village. She went to this type of business because she knows it is of big help to her and to others in need for immediate medication of common illnesses. She wanted to borrow loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP4, 000 as additional business capital for her business improvement.  

Aurora A. is already 49 years old, as a resident in their rural area, she wants to have a good health thus maintaining her selling of cheaper medicines. She knew that it is very difficult living in rural areas because far from clinic or hospitals. That reason pushes her to start her business too. She is proudly saying that her business is not just for her but it is also for the goodness of community people in their Barangay.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Josie

texts.en: Josie P. is a dedicated wife and hardworking mother who is also a businesswoman. She strives hard so that she is able to provide a good future for her two young children who are only 1 and 5 years old. Josie is 31 years old and lives in the village of Barangay Canjusa, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental, with her young family. Many of her friends look to her as a role model because of her determination to pursue her dreams and do her utmost to put up a small business and build it up so that she is able to help her husband in supporting and sustaining the needs of their family. Banking on her cooking skills, Josie decided to put a carinderia - a local eatery selling and serving a variety of cooked dishes. A carinderia is also sometimes called a "turo-turo" because the customers literally point to their choice from the array of pots containing the ready-to-eat viands. Josie joined NWTF-Project Dunganon in 2002 to access additional capital she needed to open the eatery she planned to set up adjacent to her house. From the start, she tapped the loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon to continually improve her business facilities and widen her food offerings. And because she proved to be an astute businesswoman, her business generates a good income that significantly helps provide for the support of her family, with enough left over for the savings she set up for her two children. The carinderia provides Josie with an average monthly income of PHP 9,000 which is enabling her to gradually fulfill her dreams, including saving enough to renovate and enlarge the space in her carinderia. This, so that she could have more space for the growing number of customers. In her previous loan, Josie borrowed PHP 17,000 to add to her capital and it was fully repaid without any delays. She is now borrowing PHP 17,500 for her 11th loan. She plans to use it again as revolving working capital so that she can purchase more meat and spices and expand the number and volume of her daily food offerings. She plans to save some of the profits so that she can invest in another productive asset that can contribute to the family income. The rest she plans to plow back into her carinderia business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase more meat and spices and expand her daily food offerings

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn N. is the mother of four children, all of whom are presently taking their studies. Her first child is taking his college education, two are in high school and the youngest is an elementary school pupil. Marlyn felt the difficulties in sending her children to school but, with the help of her hog-raising and duck-raising businesses, she is able to support their needs by working hard and having patience in generating income for her family.

Marlyn’s husband, Ronald, is her partner in managing their business well and they also help each other in maintaining their rice and corn field to harvest a good yield. Sometimes, Marlyn also manages to make salted eggs to retail daily. She purchases duck eggs in the market from a wholesaler and then uses them to make salted eggs.

Marlyn is happy for having been a good learner and entrepreneur. She believes that, with her ability, she will be able to succeed in her business endeavors. She therefore wants to seek PHP 5,000 financial assistance from Kiva lenders to use as additional business capital.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a seamstress. She lives in the village of San Juan Aurora, Isabela, with her husband Rolando and their children. She serves her community as a Barangay Health Worker (BHW) in their barangay. In addition to her sewing work, Nora supplements her husband's income through her direct selling business of Avon cosmetics products.

Because she wants to become a productive entrepreneur, Nora is seeking the support of lenders to allow her to borrow additional business capital amounting to PHP 5,000, to be used for the improvement of her direct selling and sewing businesses. Her business income is a great help but not enough for their daily needs, so Nora is doing her best to become progressive in her business planning.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta R. is already 39 years old. She is engage in managing a rolling store business for many years. She uses a motorcycle in selling the different goods such vegetables, meat, fish, etc. in their village of Sto.Nińo Aurora, Isabela and nearby villages. Prior to having a motorcycle that is being of big help in her rolling business, Violeta first suffer to roam her vending products by her bare foot for 18 years. She was glad that through her patience in the business, she is able to purchase an installment motorcycle for her business. 
At the moment, Violeta enjoys selling her goods in their village and even reach other villages to sell her products. Because of this expansion of her business, her goods usually are being sold out without even reaching out some of her customers thus wanted to request for additional business capital amounting to PHP20, 000 from KIVA lenders to further meet her customers requests and demands for she used to believe that customers. She hopes someday to become successful in the business and also to improve their living condition. It is really of great help said Violeta.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito B. is a farmer who lives in the village of Sto. Nińo Aurora, Isabela. He is a man with strong fighting spirit who will do anything for the future welfare of his family. He is blessed with two children: his first child is now a teacher and his youngest child is in his second year of college education. Aside from farming, Juanito also maintains a hog raising business in his yard. His business incomes enable him to pay the tuition fees of his child in school and to support and feed his family.

He wanted to take out a loan in the amount of PHP 7,000 to buy a sufficient supply of feed for his pigs. Some of the loan amount will be used topurchase another piglet to raise. Eventually, Juanito hopes to have his own pig pen where he can raise larger numbers of pigs so as to earn enough profit to improve the life of his family.

loans.use: To buy pig feed as well as to purchase a piglet to raise

loans.name: Luna

texts.en:
Luna P., age 62, is from the village of Taguilon. Luna is married and has 10 grown children. To make a living, Luna owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Luna is just starting this business.

In 2007, Luna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Luna has successfully repaid her last loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Luna is now requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Luna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Tu use as working capital and to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
At the age of 54, Leticia successfully manages to maintain two businesses: her direct selling of Avon products and her vending of food snacks and vegetables in her village of Sto. Nińo Aurora, Isabela. She is gifted with four grown children, all of whom were able to graduate with a degree thanks to her patience and determination in generating income from her direct selling and food vending businesses. She has continued in her businesses for 15 years since then.

Because she enjoys the work and to meet her personal needs, Leticia dreams of further developing her business to bring about further progress. For this reason, Leticia was encouraged to request a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 12,000 to use as additional capital for her business. Many of her customers have become more successful and she would like to offer them new and improved products. She strongly believes that the requested loan will be of great help.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her direct selling and food vending businesses

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie is engage in managing a general store business. He is able to support his family through his generated income from the business. For three years operating his store, Ronie is able to make it productive in his simple ways. He is blessed with six children who are now belongs to their school age. Some are already in their adult age. They are simply living in the village of Sto. Nińo Aurora, Isabela. 
Since his small store daily income is not enough for their daily needs, Ronie wanted to ask for financial assistance that will be use in the improvement of his store. He hopes to avail the amount of PHP10, 000, an amount he knew will be very helpful in developing his store into progress.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita G. is already 43 years old. She is engage in managing her rolling store with the aid of her motorcycle. Her vending activity daily is being made easily through her motorcycle compared to her previous vending of which she just walks around their village to retail her vending products. According to her, she had sacrifices a lot for the development of her business. And because she still was not contented in her business income, Anita wanted to request for additional business capital amounting to PHP20, 000 from the KIVA lenders. 
	Anita is able to support the education of her children through her patience and hard work maintaining her rolling store. She hopes to give them their complete education so that they will able to acquire better job in the future. Anita is also hoping that someday, she can be able to uplift their living situation into progress. Anita is anticipating that soon, KIVA lenders will lend her the assistance she is asking from them.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie J. is already 33 years old. She is engage in hog raising business. She has been two years in her business and dreaming of maintaining the business towards its development to continuously support the education of her children in school. Her family is living in the peaceful village of Bagong Tanza Aurora, Isabela. 
Josie is requesting from KIVA lenders to lend her financial assistance of around PHP9, 000 to utilize in purchasing feeds for the growth and maintenance needed by her raised pigs. She hopes that her hog raising will improve and give her family with sufficient support. She said to herself, that she will work hard and be alert to help grow her business and reach for her dreams that give benefits to her children someday.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia P. is from the village of San Pedro. She is 47 years old. Virginia is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair the engine of borrower's fishing boat. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Virginia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair the engine of borrower's fishing boat

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie S., age 55, manages a general store business in her house in Bagong Tanza Aurora, Isabela. She is requesting the amount of PHP 16,000 so to have added business capital for the improvement of her business. For the seven years she has run her store, Tessie has been able to contribute a great deal to their family necessities and has ensured the education of their children.

Tessie is blessed with three children. Some of the profits are used for business maintenance, but many of her store profits are used to support them in their studies and to pay their tuition. She actively encourages her children to finish their studies and to work very hard for their future.

Tessie is hoping to become a productive entrepreneur. To further attain her goals in life, she is patient and hardworking.

loans.use: To obtain added business capital for the improvement of her business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites A. manages a general store. Prior to managing her store, Marites had a vending business for three years. She shifted to managing a store because she got tired of roaming around her village to sell her products. Her store has been open barely six months and she hopes that it will someday progress with the help of Kiva lenders.

Marites is 37 years of age and happily married with two children who are both in school. Her income is being budgeted for her family's needs and maintaining her business. Her business is not fully productive because of her family's expenditures, and that is why Marites has requested a loan of 10,000 pesos from Kiva lenders as additional capital to improve her store.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Mercedez

texts.en:
Mercedez O. is shown in the picture posing with the motorcycle she intends to convert into a tricycle because, with the additional sidecar, it can shuttle more passengers in one trip than just a two-wheeled vehicle. Mercedez lives in the village of Brgy. Canggapas Anahaw, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is 44 years of age and married to Romeo, who presently works as a security guard. The couple is blessed with two children: her elder, a 21-year-old daughter, now works abroad and sends money home to help the family. The younger, who is 14 years old, is in high school. Mercedez knew that she could never provide her children with a better future if the family just relied on the small salary that her husband earns as a security guard; it was not even enough to properly feed the family. So she drew on her own talents and, with complete faith that God loves her and her family and would bless her endeavors, she took the plunge and became a micro entrepreneur.

When she started, Mercedez wasn't very ambitious. Her plan was just to open a business that could supplement, even in just a small way, her husband's income and probably improve their quality of life somehow. She joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 to borrow 3,000 pesos start-up capital for an electronic reloading business, selling E-load* to prepaid subscribers of mobile phone service companies.

As her income improved, she opened a refreshment shop serving local merienda (snack time) fare like batchoy (a pork and noodle soup popular in the Western Visayas region), pancit molo (wanton-wrapped pork dumplings cooked in chicken broth) and other snack fare. The new venture is symbiotically compatible with her eload business as customers in one business tend to patronize the other just because they are already in her shop. The food patrons who need load for their mobile phones buy it from her instead of going to another retailer, while load buyers stay to eat her snacks. The new venture has increased her income exponentially and it has also made Mercedes realize that she actually has good business instincts. Her later loans allowed Mercedes to improve and expand her businesses, and even to buy a motorcycle, which provides her with additional income as it shuttles passengers around the town. The businesses earn a net income of 3,000 pesos per month, which helps her pay for the education of her son and also cover some of the family's daily expenses.

Mercedez borrowed 12,000 pesos with her previous loan, and she was able to pay it back in weekly installments without any delays. She is borrowing 15,000 pesos now on her seventh loan cycle. She plans to use the money to buy a sidecar for the motorcycle to increase its income potential, and she also intends to use any money left over for the other business ventures.

*Eload - is a service that allows prepaid mobile phone subscribers to buy load from retailers so that they can continue using the mobile phone service when they have consumed the service credits on their cellular phones. Demand for this kind of service is high because cell phones are a must-have for most Filipinos, but the low-end market prefer the prepaid service because there are no fixed monthly charges; the availability of the cellphone service depends on the amount of load credits they purchase. Retailers get a percentage commission from the load amount they sell.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta sells ripe bananas and some vegetables in her village, twice a month. She also has a livestock business (hog-raising) as an added source of income to meet her family's daily needs.

Loreta is 56 years of age and married to Bartolome A., who is a farmer. They are blessed with 11 children: three of them are already married and eight children are still single. There are only five family members living at home, including the parents, because some of the children work as family helpers in other places to help earn money. Her family lives in the distant village of Casalatan Cauayan City, Isabela. The place is located in the forest region of Cauayan City.

Loreta is able to earn around 500 pesos net income with her biweekly sales. She would like a loan of 7,000 pesos for further improvement of her business. Loreta hopes that someday her simple business will become a big and stable business earning more income for her family.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is already 43 years of age, she is married to a farm laborer named Macario S., they are blessed with five children, they are; Rex - 20 years of age, elementary graduate, followed by Ronald - 17 years old, he is also an elementary graduate, next to him is Rommel - 12 years old, grade four student, Dario - nine years old, grade two student, and their youngest is Sta. Maria – one year old. They are harmoniously residing at Barangay Casalatan Cauayan City, part of Cauayan City forest region. 

	Vegetable vending is her business for almost five years. She is earning around PHP120 in her every vending activity. She only sells twice a week because she doesn’t have enough capital to utilize for the regularity of her business. In this regard, Delia wanted to borrow loan from KIVA amounting to PHP4, 000 as additional capital for the development of her vending business. She hopes to improve the business because her family relies from her business incomes.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Emmalyn

texts.en:
Emmalyn is already 27 years old, she manages a hog raising business to gain income for her family needs. She disposes her fully grown up pigs after four months. For every pig, Emmalyn is able to generate income of PHP3, 000 that is being used to sustain their immediate necessities at home. She plans to avail a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP 4, 000 to purchase hog feeds that her hog raising needed to sustain their daily feeds supply. 

	 Emmalyn is married to Joseph C., he is a farmer. They have two children namely; Jocelyn, 11 years of age, and Helen Joyce, nine years old, both are presently elementary students. Her whole family lives in the far place of Casalatan Cauayan City, Isabela. She hopes to give their two children with complete education despite the distance of available school from their place. Emmalyn further said that; in every man’s struggles, he must be willing to sacrifice to become successful.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta C. is from the village of Minang. She is 65 years old. Marietta is married and has 1 adult-aged child. Marietta owns & operates a business running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marietta has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2006, Marietta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marietta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Marietta is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Marietta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Lirio

texts.en:
Lirio and her husband Francisco B. are blessed with a big family. They have 13 children. Nine of them are already married and four are still living with and dependent on them since they don’t have jobs due to low educational attainment. They are living simply in the village of Casalatan Cauayan City, Isabela. It is a forested area which does not physically show the forest region, which most people call the place.

She has been involved in a livestock business, which is hog raising, for almost 35 years. She earns income from the business that is being utilized for the needs of her big family. She wanted to borrow a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 4,000 as additional business capital so that her hog raising business will become progressive. The loan will be of great help in purchasing a stock of feed in the market, which is really very far from their village, to give her livestock a sufficient supply of feed until they grow ready for disposal.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria tiene 27 años, es una joven madre de familia muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Linder y a sus 2 hijos: Densi de 5 y Edy de 1 año y lo que más desea es mejorar su calidad de vida. Su puesto de carne está ubicado en el mercado Las Mercedes (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), su negocio le es muy rentable, ya que es muy concurrido por las personas y casi todos los días acaba con la mercadería que tenía planeado vender, lo cual la hace muy feliz, ya que sabe que ese dinero ayudará a su familia a tener una mejor vida. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta sobre las cosas que suceden en el mercado, lleva 8 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer en su puesto de venta, soportando el intenso frió, aun así no se desanima y sigue adelante. Para el futuro anhela tener una carnicería más grande fuera del mercado, con la cual pueda mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
Este es el segundo préstamo de Gloria con MFP y está muy contenta de haberlo obtenido, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo para no perjudicar a las demás socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más carne para implementar mejor su puesto de venta.
texts.en:
Gloria is 27 years old. She is a young mother who comes from a hardworking family. She lives in her own home together with her husband Linder and their two children, Densi, who is 5 years old, and Edy, who is only 1. Gloria's greatest desire is to improve the quality of life for her children. Her small butcher shop is located in the Las Mercedes market, the most important market in the city of Juliaca. Her business is doing well. She has many customers and almost every day she manages to sell what she planned. This makes her happy, because she knows that the income will help improve her family's quality of life. What she enjoys most about her work is the chance to talk with other vendors nearby about what's happening in the market. Gloria has had this business for 8 years, and even though she has to work at her shop when it's intensely cold, she remains motivated and continues to work hard. In the future, she would like to have a much larger butcher shop outside of the market, where she could generate more income. This is the second loan from MFP, and she is very content to have received this support. Gloria knows that she must make all of the payments on time so that the reputation of all the communal bank members is upheld. With the money, she will purchase meat to stock her small business.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase meat for her small butcher shop

loans.name: Facunda

texts.es:
Facunda tiene 63 años, es una madre muy amorosa y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su menor hijo Yhon de 12 años, a quien desea dar unos buenos estudios. El negocio al que se dedica es la compra y venta de fibra de ovino, su puesto está ubicado en el mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), el cual es muy concurrido, ya que sus clientes saben que la calidad de fibra que encontrarán es muy buena y además obtendrán un precio muy cómodo. Lo que más le gusta a Facunda de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes y aconsejarlos en su compra, lleva 15 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día dentro de su puesto sin poder salir. Para el futuro espera hacer crecer su negocio y poder tener una tienda más grande, la cual le genere mejores ingresos económicos.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Facunda con MFP, se siente en la responsabilidad de pagarlo a tiempo, puesto que no quiere meter en problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida debido a la alegría que pone en las reuniones. Con los quinientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más fibra de ovino para implementar mejor su puesto de venta.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana tiene 46 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora y decidida, vive en la casa de sus familiares, junto a su esposo Rubén de 48 años y sus 2 hijos: Rubén de 18 y Jakelin de 8 años, a quienes desea dar una mejor vida. La venta de carne le ha dado a Juana los ingresos necesarios par mantener a su familia, ella tiene su puesto en el mercado Las mercedes (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), el cual es muy concurrido, ya que la carne que vende es muy fresca y sabrosa, lo cual le ha hecho una buena fama y le trae mucho clientes. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es aconsejar a sus clientes sobre la carne que más sabor le dará a sus comidas, lleva 30 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta sin poder salir. Para el futuro espera tener una carnicería más grande en la cual pueda atender mejor a sus clientes.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Juana con MFP y se siente en la responsabilidad de pagarlo a tiempo, aunque para ello tenga que ahorrar poco a poco. En su banco comunal es una socia muy activa y solidaria, motivo por el cual es muy respetada por sus compañeros. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más carne, ya que últimamente la demanda a crecido.
texts.en:
Juana is 46 years old and very hardworking and decisive. She lives together with her husband Ruben, who is 48 years old, and their two children, ages 18 and 8. She would like to improve the quality of life for her children. Running her butcher shop has provided the income Juana needs to help support her family. She has a small stand in the Las Mercedes market, the most important market in the city of Juliaca. She has many customers, and she is well known for the quality and freshness of the meat she sells. What she enjoys most about her work is being able to offer advice to her customers about which cuts of meat provide the best flavor for the meals they prepare. Juana has been doing this work for 30 years. It is very hard work as she needs to be at her small stand all day and cannot leave. In the future, she would like to have a larger butcher shop where she'll be better able to serve more customers. This is Juana's third loan with MFP, and she is responsible in making timely payments, though she must save little by little. In her communal bank, Juana is an active member and team player, winning her the respect of fellow members. With the money from this loan, she will purchase more meat to sell, as lately she has had more demand from her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase meat to stock her small butcher shop in the market

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
Paula tiene 50 años, es una madre muy alegre, vive en su propia casa junto a su esposo Víctor D. 76 años y sus 2 hijas gemelas: Maria Rosario y Maria Angélica D. 10 años, a quienes desea dar una buena vida. El negocio D. venta D. frutas que tiene Paula le ha dado los ingresos necesarios para mantener a su familia, junto a su triciclo sale todas las mañanas a vender las deliciosas frutas que compró en el mercado mayorista, ella venD. en la Explanada Laguna Temporal (lugar donD. se realizan ferias en la ciudad D. Juliaca). Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas D. venta, lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en la calle bajo los sofocantes rayos solares. Para el futuro espera tener una tienda D. abarrotes donD. pueda vender con más comodidad y mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
Este es el cuarto préstamo D. Paula con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo. En su banco comunal siempre está al tanto D. todos los acuerdos a los que lleguen en su grupo. Con los mil setecientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más frutas para poder ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad para escoger.
texts.en:
Paula is 50 year old. She is a happy mother of two twin girls age 10, Maria Rosario and Maria Angelica. They live together with Paula's husband Victor, who is 76. Paula wants to proviD. her girls with a good life. Paula's business selling fruit has provided the income she needs to help proviD. for her family. On her bike and wagon, she heads out every morning to sell the delicious fruit she has purchased wholesale. She sells the fruit in a marketplace in the city of Juliaca. What she enjoys most about her work is the chance to talk with other vendors in the market. Paula has had this business for 10 years, and the most difficult part is working all day under the hot sun. In the future, she hopes to have a small grocery shop where she can sell under more comfortable conditions and increase her income. This is the fourth loan for Paula with MFP, and she knows the importance of making the payments on time. In her communal bank, she always complies with the agreements maD. by her group. With the money from this loan, she will purchase more fruit so that she can offer her customers a greater variety from which to choose.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of fruit to sell to her customers

loans.name: Semona

texts.es:
Semona tiene 45 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a sus 3 hijos: Carlos de 15, Miguel de 12 y Jhosep de 10 años, quienes son el motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. Todas las mañanas Semona sale junto a su triciclo a vender el rico jugo de quinua que prepara (jugo caliente hecho a base de quinua licuada, maicena y manzana), la bebida caliente que prepara es muy solicitada, ya que las bajas temperaturas que hay por las mañanas en su región incitan a las personas a tomar algo caliente. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo, es que puede tomar los vasos de jugo que desea cuando tiene hambre, lleva 5 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que despertarse temprano y salir a las frías calles a para vender. Para el futuro anhela tener una tienda donde pueda vender con mayor tranquilidad y atender mejor a sus clientes. 
Este es el segundo préstamo de Semona con MFP y se siente muy confiada de poder pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que no quiere causar problemas en su banco comunal, donde es muy querida, ya que es una persona muy alegre. Con los seiscientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más ingredientes para preparar el delicioso jugo de quinua que vende.
texts.en:
Semona is a very hardworking 45-year-old woman who lives in her own home with her three children: Carlos, 15; Miguel, 12; and Jhosep, 10. Her children are the reason behind her efforts. Every morning Semona goes out with her three-wheeled cart to sell delicious quinoa juice (hot juice made from liquidized quinoa, cornstarch, and apples) that she makes herself. The hot beverage is in great demand because in this region temperatures are cool in the mornings, which encourages people to drink something warm. What Semona likes most about her work is that she can drink the glasses of juice she wants when she's hungry. She has been in this line of work for 5 years and believes that the hardest part is having to wake up early and go out in the cold streets in order to sell. In the future she longs to have a store where she can work with greater ease and better serve her customers. This is Semona's second loan with MFP (Microfinanzas Prisma) and she feels very confident that she will be able to make her payments on time. She doesn’t want to cause any problems with her community bank where she is beloved for being such a happy person. She will use the 600 Peruvian soles (US$225) to buy more ingredients in order to make the delicious quinoa juice that she sells.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to make juice

loans.name: Lucenas

texts.en:
Lucenas B. is from the village of Nazareth, Buenavista, Pagadian City. She is 49 years old. Lucenas is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lucenas owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Lucenas has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately  PHP a month for these activities.

Lucenas joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucenas is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lucenas from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Sulma

texts.es:
Sulma tiene 26 años, es una joven muy trabajadora y responsable y vive en la casa de sus padres, a quienes desea ayudar en los gastos y del hogar y dejar de ser una carga familiar. El negocio al que Sulma se dedica es la venta de fibra de ovino, su puesto está ubicado en el mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), ella es una vendedora muy alegre y carismática, lo cual ha hecho que tenga muchos clientes, además tiene una fama, muy bien ganada, de vender fibra de muy buena calidad. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta y así hacer más amenas sus largas jornadas de trabajo, lleva 4 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer en su puesto de venta en espera de clientes. Para el futuro anhela tener una tienda de abarrotes, la cual, junto a su actual negocio, le ayudaría a mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Este es el tercer préstamo de Sulma con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que siente que tiene una responsabilidad con las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy respetada y querida. Con los seiscientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más fibra de ovino para ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad.
texts.en:
Sulma is 26 years old. She is a hardworking and responsible young woman who lives at home with her parents. She desires to help with the household expenses because she does not want to be a burden to her family.

Sulma sells wool from her vending stall at the San José Market (the largest market in the city of Juliaca). She is a cheerful and charismatic saleswoman who has many clients and has earned a good reputation because of the high quality wool she offers. What she enjoys most about her job is talking with the neighbors who buy from her, which makes her long work days more pleasant. Sulma has been in business for 4 years and the most difficult part is remaining at her sales post the entire day in order to wait for customers. In the future, she hopes to open a grocery store in addition to her current business, which will help improve her quality of life.

This is Sulma’s third loan with MFP. She is willing to make her payments on time because she feels responsible to the other members of her Communal Bank, who she greatly respects and admires. Her loan of 600 soles will be used to buy more wool so that she can provide her customers with more variety.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her inventory of wool

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria tiene 43 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus familiares junto a su esposo, Teofilo de 50 años, y juntos planean salir adelante y mejorar su calidad de vida.	Edad, estado civil, miembros de su familia. La actividad diaria de Victoria es la venta de carne, tiene su puesto en el mercado Las Mercedes (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), el cual es muy concurrido, ya que siempre vende carne de muy buena calidad, ella es una vendedora muy alegre y recibe a sus clientes con una sonrisa en los labios. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta, lleva 3 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta sin poder salir. Para el futuro espera tener una carnicería más grande donde pueda atender mejor a sus clientes.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Victoria con MFP y espera no fallar en los pagos de sus cuotas, en su banco comunal es una socia muy comprometida y solidaria. Con los mil quinientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más carne para implementar mejor su puesto de venta.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería

loans.name: Maria Jundi

texts.en:
Maria Jundi is from the village of Daanglungsod. She is 36 years old. Maria Jundi is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Jundi owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing passenger's vehicle services to local community members. Maria Jundi has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Maria Jundi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Jundi has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for franchise and registration renewal of the transport vehicle. Maria Jundi is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to repair the said transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Erlinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements of their house and to pay tuition fees of their children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: America

texts.es:
América tiene 33 años, es una madre muy dedicada y trabajadora, vive en una casa alquilada junto a su esposo Carlos, de 34 años, y sus 2 hijos: Renato de 11 y Anthony de 9 años, a quienes desea dar una mejor calidad de vida. Se dedica a la venta de balones de gas, tiene su propia distribuidora en la casa donde vive, desde donde envía los balones a las personas que llaman solicitando uno, generalmente como combustible para las cocinas. El negocio le va bien y le está dando los ingresos necesarios para mantener a su familia. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que le permite atender las labores de su hogar y cuidar su negocio al mismo tiempo, lleva 1 año con esta actividad y considera que aunque es un negocio muy peligroso, por las probabilidades que hay de la explosión de un balón, lo sigue haciendo, pues es su fuente de ingresos económicos. Para el futuro espera tener una tienda de abarrotes, la cual le genere unos mejores ingresos económicos.
Este es el sexto préstamo de América con MFP y espera no fallar en los pagos de sus cuotas, en su banco comunal es una socia muy comprometida y solidaria. Los mil nuevos soles solicitados los invertirá en compra de más balones de gas para implementar  mejor su negocio.
texts.en:
América is 33 years old; she is a very dedicated and hard working mother. She rents a house with her husband Carlos, age 34, and their two children: 11-year old Renato and 9-year old Anthony. América hopes to provide them with a better quality of life. She sells propane cylinders from her home, distributing the cylinders by phone request to her customers, who use them mostly for cooking. Business is good and she is earning enough income to support her family. What América likes the most about her work is that it allows her to do house work and have a small business at the same time. She has had this business for a year and although it is dangerous, due to the possibility that a cylinder could explode, she will continue it because it is a good source of income. In the future América hopes to have a grocery store, which would generate even better income. This is her sixth loan with MFP and she doesn't expect to miss any of her repayments. In her community bank she is a very committed and supportive member. The 9,000 PEN she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of gas cylinders to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing inventory.

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena tiene 44 años, es una madre muy amorosa y vive en su casa propia junto a  su hijo Ronal de 18 años, a quien desea dar unos buenos estudios superiores. El puesto de venta de fibra de alpaca de Elena está ubicado en la explanada Laguna Temporal (lugar donde se realizan ferias en la ciudad de Juliaca). Su negocio es muy concurrido, ya que sus clientes saben que ahí podrán encontrar fibra de buena calidad y a un bajo precio, lo que ha hecho que su negocio marche muy bien. Lo que más le gusta a Elena de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta, lleva 14 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer en su puesto de venta todo el día. Para el futuro espera que su negocio crezca y le brinde mejores ingresos económicos.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Elena con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que quiere acceder a otros préstamos posteriormente. En su banco comunal es una de las socias más responsables. Con los mil ochocientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más fibra para implementar mejor su puesto.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
Guillermina tiene 39 años, es una mujer muy luchadora y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia y lo que más desea es sobre salir en la vida.
